<question from>

Member since: 15 September 2008
Total points: 103 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Now That America Has Their First Black President, Will We Ever See The First Women President?



I voted for Obama and am happy he won. But I don't think a Women should ever be President Of The United States.



Why You Ask, I Think Bill Maher put it perfectly.



Here is what he said:



Bill Maher: I’m not trying to be sexist here, but I’m just saying that women try a lot of different tacks when they’re in arguments.



[Plays a clip of Hillary, misty-eyed at a campaign event]



Maher: But look at Hillary Clinton. Because the first thing a woman does, of course, is cry. [Affecting a dramatic, teary voice] “I just want to be happy. Why can’t you just love me?”



Maher: And then they go to sweet talking.



[Plays a clip of Hillary complimenting Obama at a recent debate]



Maher: “You’re the best thing that ever happened to me! And you look so handsome in that tie!”



[Plays a clip of Hillary saying “shame on you” about Obama’s “Harry and Louise” brochure]



Maher: And then they throw an anger fit totally unrelated to anything. “Stay home and watch the game. See if I care.”



[Plays a clip of Hillary mocking Obama’s soaring rhetoric]



Maher: And when it doesn’t work, they bring out the sarcasm. “Oh, I’m just a woman, I couldn’t possibly understand the issues like you could.” Don’t write me, please ladies, don’t write me.



Christopher Hitchens: And then if you say “whine, whine, whine,” they say that’s sexist.



Not to mention when that time of the month comes, she might just accidentaly nuke a country.



Women just can’t handle the tough job of being a leader much less the leader of the United States, the toughest job in the world.



</question>



<answer from>

Member since: 25 December 2007
Total points: 2793 (Level 4)



</answer from>

<question>



Why is it that people become more recognized only after death?



It seems to be the case for innumerable people that their talent and contributions in the world become recognized as something great only after their death?



I can think of a few reasons, but I want to hear what the good people of YA have to say about it.



</question>



<additional details>



Great reasons, Bart :)



</additional details>



<answer from>



Bart
Member since: 27 April 2008
Total points: 254 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



It makes their work more valuable (if it's something tangible).  If they are still alive, they could contribute countless more, and their best work could be ahead of them.  Also, respect for the dead.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



True.



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



alyssaaa...
Member since: 12 May 2008
Total points: 2437 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



well, i guess it depends on the person. if that perticular person did great things when they were alive, and helped many people, when theyre gone, people will notice the change in their world and start to realize how valuable and loved that person is.



</answer>



<answer from>



godsnori...
Member since: 27 March 2006

I don't know, the same reason we take everything for granted and cry when it leaves.

Bella

Total points: 617 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



What do you think of interracial relationships?



I am curious what people think of this subject. I was raised with the beliefs that you stick to your own race & I have. I am white & my husband is white & our daughter is white & I will pass on the same beliefs to her. I would be very very upset if she ever dated or married out side of her own race. To be honest, and this is NOT to offend anyone, just my personal opinion, I don't like seeing interracial couples, especially black & white. I also hate it when they have kids as I feel they come out very homely (Most of the time). I think that black couples look good together & they normally have great looking kids but when they mix to me it just doesn't look good, they don't match, it looks odd. Again this is not to sound racist, sorry if it offends you. How do you feel when you see an interracial couple? PS: I would never ever be rude or disrespectful to anyone just because of their race, this is strictly based on looks that I am speaking about, although there are many cultural differences in many races.



</question>



<additional details>



Sorry but not all kids are beautiful. I have seen plenty of ugly ones and most were mixed.



</additional details>



<answer from>



vic
Member since: 05 October 2008
Total points: 164 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I think interracial relationships are ok.I am not in one my self but my oppinion is that it does not matter what colour your skin is or where you are from as long as you love each other and it certainly does not matter if you look good as a couple or not as its whats inside that counts not the outside.



</answer>



<answer from>



the X
Member since: 02 December 2006
Total points: 6752 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



i dont care, we have to be socially progressive.



</answer>



<answer from>



starrchy...
Member since: 03 June 2007
Total points: 1155 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



I personally don't see the problem.  I'm a black woman and with the exception of my ex, I've only dated white men.  It's not that I don't like black men, I've just always been attracted to white men.  I've met plenty of white men who treat me with respect and act like they have sense.  So what if their skin color is different than mine.



As far as looks go,  I think that's a shallow reason to dislike interracial couples. Sorry, to sound like I'm bashing you, but I think it's true.  If two "ugly" people were together, would that be wrong?  I also disagree with the "homely" children comment.  I believe that most interracial children, especially those who have one black and one white parent, are beautiful.  ALL children are beautiful.



I would never impose such rules on my children.  It would be next to impossible to raise my children that way while explaining to them that it's not a racist view.  Just because you say it isn't, doesn't mean it isn't.  If you single someone out or exclude them in any way because of skin color, that's racist.  Plain and simple.  It doesn't mean you're going to go throw on your robe and burn crosses on peoples' lawns, but it's racist all the same.



</answer>



<answer from>

<answer from>



piratesa...
Member since: 13 June 2008
Total points: 129 (Level 1)

<answer>



My family has spent many years in the military, all the male members but one served and some family members even retired from the military. I can tell you that while in service, we never knew the whys or what-fors of war. The conclusion that I have arrived at is this: Nobody really knows. It could have started by accident, it could have started by disagreement, it could have started because one country invaded and accused  another country of having something they did not have. I personally believe it is all about power and money. No one is really happy with the amount of power they have so they want more... and are willing to do anything they have to do just to get a little more.



So in a nut shell.... I do not think that we the common people will ever know the truth behind war.



</answer>

<original file>13087.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk102849.txt</current file name>




<category>



Society & Culture



Other - Society & Culture



</category>



<question from>



IwannaGo...
Member since: 18 December 2006
Total points: 7588 (Level 5)



</question from>



<question>



Whom do you live for?



my brother told me i only live for myself.
i want to study abroad, i went (here i am)
i only went home for a week after a year, and the first next vacation i have, i'd rather do an internship than go home again.



i think he's right.
and i don't think that's wrong what i do.
i've always lived to fulfill other's expectation on me back at "home"
that's why i find my destiny abroad.



where i could actually be myself.
without having to fit in just to satisfy what "my society" expect of me.



whom do you live for?



(i'm 23, btw. please tell me how old you are when you answer.



thx.)



</question>



<answer from>



piratesa...
Member since: 13 June 2008
Total points: 129 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



There is a fine balance when dealing with self achievement and family obligations. Especially when you are so young. When I was 23 (I am 40 now) I had no problem blowing off family "things" to follow my dreams and my desires. On one hand i love that I did what I wanted to do but on the other I feel some regret that I missed out on some family "things" as well.



There is nothing wrong for living for yourself, BUT... if your family is important too, then you want to find a balance so you do not have regrets in the end.



Trust me, the last thing you want is to say the sentence " I love that I traveled abroad and love that I followed my dream, but i regret...



In the end, you have to do what you feel you need to do, just think about the entire picture... not just the short term.



Me, at this point in my life I live for my mother who has Alzheimer's Disease, I live for my three rescue dogs who were severely beaten and abused and I live for me. I did college, and grad school and military and I now have a small business I try to run from home and care for my family. Would I do things differently? I am not sure...



Peace



</answer>



<answer from>



De Falco
Member since: 14 July 2008
Total points: 1978 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



When you are young and have no kids, it's ok to live for yourself first...but not only for yourself. I'm 47 and I live for my kids and my new grand daughter (3 wks old!)...then myself.



</answer>

<answer from>



indian ponnu

<answer>



One of the reasons that men should put the toilet down is to keep women in the home from falling into the toilet. Women go to the restroom more times a day then men. Men might ask why a woman would fall into the toilet. First, we usually leave the bathroom light off so that it does not wake you in the middle of the night. Aren't we nice? <question>



Do you think that Tiger Woods is ashamed of his African American heritage?



I know that Tiger Woods is multiracial. But he also has African American heritage. He told a reporter that he was not black but he is "one-quarter Black, one-quarter Thai, one-quarter Chinese, one-eighth American Indian and one-eighth White"



Wouldn't it have been better if Tiger Woods said he was not only black but Asian, white etc as well. Or wouldn't it be better if he said I am white, black, Asian etc. If people called Tiger Woods Asian do you think he would  have stated he was not Asian? I personally don't think that Tiger Woods would have ever married an African American woman. What do you think? Do you believe he is ashamed of his African American heritage?



</question>

<question from>



That one Lady
Member since: 08 October 2006
Total points: 3852 (Level 4)



</question from>



<question>



If I'm not home for a UPS package, will they leave it on the door step? ?



I can't be home tomorrow to receive a package that's supposed to come, it's fairly small and I know from previous experience that they'll sometimes leave it on the doorstep, otherwise they leave a note for you to come pick it up. How do I know which they will do?



</question>



<answer from>



Brokeback Brady
Member since: 15 July 2008
Total points: 608 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



depends on the item.  Usually expensive items such as computers need a sig.  If you are just getting shoes or something they will leave it at the door.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



It's a book so I'm assuming it'll be left at the door. THANKS!



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



V Aletheia
Member since: 09 September 2008
Total points: 1115 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



You can talk to your neighbor/s and ask them to hold the package for you so you know it's safe (if you trust them, that is).
Otherwise it might end up sitting there in the open for any curious passerby to tamper with.



Call UPS and tell them you want it left with your neighbor, or write a note on your door so they know.



</answer>



<answer from>



Murzy
Member since: 17 May 2008
Total points: 12878 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



depends if the driver feels it's safe to leave it. however, if it were sent with a "signature required", he will not leave it.



</answer>



<answer from>

Member since: 20 February 2008

<answer from>

Total points: 4845 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



As many races as exist on earth...



Humans have a 'Wander Lust' and from the dawn of man kind we have been wandering the globe...



With the advancements in transportation, there is no race on earth that is not represented in Asia...



BTW... Asia is HUGE!!!! You would be better off asking for the racial diversity in a specific area...



Asking about "Asia" is like asking about "South America" or "Europe".



The sheer size of the area means that there is no real way to pin point specifics...



</answer>

<answer>

Tucson Arizona is a good 2nd though... Decent economy, a VERY interesting mix of characters...

<answer>



I don't think too many men hold these views in this day and age. But it is increasingly common for men to feel that they are the victims of inequality. Here in Britain many aspects of law favour women at the expense of men :



- women can get a court injunction against a man without any evidence; her word is enough.



- men in England only win 1% of child custody cases.



- where a man reports being assaulted by his partner, he is likely to be the one who gets arrested in 40% of cases, despite being the victim.



- the UK government spends £60m per year on women's refuges, and not a penny on men's.



- a man is two and a half times as likely to be jailed than a woman, for exactly the same crime.
- a woman is twice as likely to be given a discharge (conviction without punishment) than a man for exactly the same crime.



- widows get a pension from the state. Widowers do not.
- men get fleeced in divorce cases, and often lose their home.
- men get fleeced by the Child Support Agency. Over 90% of those who it targets are men. It unfairly apportions blame for a failed relationship, and puts that blame squarely on the man in almost every instance, and indirectly punishes any new family he may have, and fails to address the problem of how the money is spent. Courts used to make far more realistic and fair Child Support orders.



Men are finding now that institutionalised feminism is in practice institutionalised misandry. Harriet Harman, the Minister for Women and "Equality" (?) even wants to give women accused of murder a legal defence that her male victim had the potential to be violent at some point in the future, which would make it okay for her to kill a man as he sleeps! You couldn't make it up!



Edit - just a thought to add. If there is a feeling that people hold those views (ie men) then it is women's fault. Women understandably generally spend more time with the children on average. Therefore women get to have more influence on their children. So if children are being raised with sexist views based on gender stereotypes, then it must be mostly the fault of women themselves. Why did they not do more to educate their sons and daughters, and show them that men and women are equal, and that women can have careers?



Source(s):



Office of National Statistics
British Crime Survey
http://blogs.telegraph.co.uk/gerald_warn...



</answer>

<category>



Society & Culture



Other - Society & Culture



</category>



<question from>



Amy R
Member since: 08 April 2008
Total points: 178 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



What does someone need to do to be a mentor?



My boss and I don't have much of a relationship, but he wants to build a mentoring relationship with me. He wants to know what I need from him in order for him to be effecitve in this manner.



All I can think of is conversation and helping to find out my goals in my career. The thing is, my boss is very quiet and reserved. So when he tries to talk about those things, it just seems really forced.



Any ideas about how else he can strive to be my mentor that won't make it all feel so force with the 'conversation' piece?



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



Firstly your boss shouldn't really be your mentor. Part of a mentors role is to allow you to talk to you openly about your job and any difficulties you  are having then approach your boss for you and discuss ways forward that work for you and the company. However having said this it could still work. Being a mentor is about sharing experiences, having an 'open door' policy and helping you to identify realistic goals and empowering you to achieve them. A good mentoring relationship develops when you have common ground with your mentor and you respect their achievements and successes and they are motivated and able to help you succeed in your own right.



</answer>

<question>



What could this dream mean?



In the dream:



I went to my old house in California, where there are now tenents. I was on my bridge that was outside of my house and called her (with her own phone which was sitting on the bridge) saying that "Hey I'm outside on the bridge, is it ok? Would you feel uncomfortable?" When she said no, It started raining hard. I put the phone down and started to Dance remembering my old times in elementry and with my parents. The streets were empty. Suddenly I missed this guy that I am in love with. (He stopped talking to me and started to ignore me for some reason that he never told me. The end of our friendship was mysterious.) Well, so again I pick up her phone and call him (in Texas). Somehow my Dad picks up the phone and says "hello" kinda like it was transferred somehow or something. It was the guy's number though. Anyways So i talk a little and hang up.. I was really sad and crying. When the neighbour came out with her daughter she was kind of consoling me. I was like "there isnt anyone anymore that I can share my childhood with anymore." When I started to leave, this good looking guy (that i have always felt a "brotherly bond" to. He's on a tv show) grabbed my hand with a smileand said "LET'S GO!! YOU CAN SHOW ME!!" Well then I wa happy again and it felt like he was really close to me. We went through the playground and I told him my struggles and everything. He was actually listening to me. So when we got there there were students playing around on the fields, and teachers for some reason were out there with tables out and they were preparing something. Well I went up to a lady and asked her if it was ok if I took him to tour the school.. She said ok. I asked her if there were any teachers and she said no. I named a few and she said ya maybe. well I asked her about my pre-k teacher and she said "this is her" pointing at the lady on the wall. That teacher looked SOO different. She dyed her hair. I didnt think she'd recognise me but she hugged me saying "thanks for meeting me" and she gave me her email address.. What could this mean?

<answer>



Last night was just another night among many.  The President of the U.S. is a figure head position the same as the Queen of England.  The President himself (or herself) has no actual power to do anything he (or she) promises on the campaign trail.  CONGRESS runs the country and SPECIAL INTEREST GROUPS run congress.



All you McCain-ites and Obama-ites are truly naive if you think it matters one whit who is President.  The only way a particular party's agenda goes forward is if they control congress.  Right now we have a democratic congress so expect to see change on the horizon because of a democratic congress - not because of a democratic President.



As for everyone who made this election an issue of color, would you have voted for McCain if he'd been black and Obama had been white?  I think it's terrific that a black man can be President the same as a white one, a Hispanic one or a "Whatever" one, but find it hard to believe that anyone would vote for the President of one of the most powerful countries in the world on the basis of race rather than confidence in the person's credentials and track record.



</answer>

<question>



Why are so many people calling Barack Obama "black"...?



... when he is, in fact, mixed race.



Are the individuals who do it blind, or just plain stupid?



Have they forgotten that his mother was as white as his father was black, or is it something they need to ignore in their haste to espouse painfully racist propaganda?



I'm just grateful that Obama himself seems to stand beyond the petty racial issues that seem to mean so much to the idiot racist factions of both black and white America.



But how long will it be before the rest of the world catches on and gets over their racial hangups?



</question>



<answer from>



sammie baybee :)
Member since: 05 November 2008
Total points: 109 (Level 1)

<answer>



because though he is not fully black he has black in him and thats more black than any other president we have ever had.

<answer from>



xixxvmcm...
Member since: 17 June 2008
Total points: 1316 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



What's wrong with saying he's Black? He IS Black. He is also White. One not need to qualify the statement with a percentage for it to be true.



I agree that the senator is handling the race issue with much more grace than many Americans. It's a shame that we're still not quite over race, yet nobody said it was going to be an easy and quick process.



Problem is we still have a fragmented society, very few places are truly "integrated".



Here in the SF Bay Area (CA) racism is practically a non-issue because for the most part one can find representation of just about any race in any city (though there are of course certain districts within cities that have ethnic majorities).



Most of the US is far from this ideal. We still have entire cities that are either/or Black or White, and until we see a more even integration I'm afraid racism will still be present.



</answer>

<answer>



The history of American racial identity for people of any African descent has included the "one drop rule", where the law in colonial times designated anyone with "one drop of black blood" as black to maintain the "purity" of the white race.  We have moved far beyond this history of ignorance but in many corners, it still prevails.

<answer from>



emaleari...
Member since: 09 December 2007
Total points: 5052 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



As a rape survivor, I can't really be objective about this issue. In my mind I have invented many, many heinous & cruel punishments for these bastards, most of which would never be approved of by the general public.  I definitely believe a lonnnng prison sentence~at the very least 10 to 15 years, & more if it was a particularly violent rape or was warranted by other circumstances.  I also think they should have to "repay society" in some other way, something that might help them realize the reality of what they've done to another human being.  (Without having to expose them to other victims.)  I also think that they should have to pay for the victim's therapy, medical treatment including abortion costs, & any other costs incurred as a direct result.



Unless you've been through something like rape~especially a violent rape where the victim was in danger of losing their life, you can't imagine what you go through. It changes every aspect of your life, & becomes a part of it.  The world becomes a completely different place,



& you no longer enjoy the freedoms that you once took for granted. You become a prisoner in your own psychological hell.



Rape isn't "just" having sex with someone you really didn't want to have sex with.  It's about losing control over your own body. It's about fear. And living with the nightmare EVERY day for the rest of your life.  As far as I'm concerned, there IS no punishment strong enough. Nothing can give you back that part of your soul once someone has stolen it.
PS.  To the "You have to put it behind you etc." posters... don't. You don't know the situation, so don't assume you do.  Thanks.



</answer>

Being referred to by such classifications is not necessarily meant in a pejorative way.

A person of colour

Negro,



(not considered nice but caucasian is acceptable for white people)



African American

Black,



(plain and simple and commonly used in the UK)

<original file>20575.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk111169.txt</current file name>




<category>



Society & Culture



Other - Society & Culture



</category>



<question from>



eastside...
Member since: 29 April 2008
Total points: 104 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Can Females Be Juniors?



Can females be juniors like males are juniors? Example: If my moms name is Susan Michelle Pharr, and she has a daughter, and names her Susan Michelle Pharr, could the daughter be considered Susan Michelle Pharr Jr.(or II)?



</question>



<answer from>



emaleari...
Member since: 09 December 2007
Total points: 5054 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Great question!  I don't think it's ever been done, but of course times are changing and I think that it could work, depending on whether or not the mother retains her maiden name.
If the mother takes the father's name, it won't work, since the child's last name would be his.  Traditionally, women have given their maiden names as middle names (my mother did that) but sometimes the last name may not fit.  The parents would have to work it out, because usually even when a mother keeps her own last name, the child takes the father's name.  It's confusing, there should be a way to do it, but there are a lot of factors to take into consideration.  I HAVE seen a couple of companies though, that were named "Jones and Daughters" (or whatever the name was) instead of "Sons" & that was nice to see!



EDIT:  You know, I don't think I really understood your question at first.  Your mom COULD put Susan Michelle Pharr II~ I suppose, but I think it would become part of her last name?  Not sure, but I think it goes like this:  Sam Jones has a son, so the son is "jr"  Then Sam Jones Jr. has a son, & HE would be Sam Jones II.  His son would be the III, etc.  I'm not positive about this, but I remember someone telling me that. So in that case, your mom could name her daughter "jr" (most forms have that option) but when Susan Jr. had a daughter, she wouldn't be able to name her the II, because she would have her husbands last name. (?)  LOL, very good question!



</answer>



<answer from>



Musica
Member since: 05 July 2006
Total points: 24798 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Other - Society & Culture



</answer from>



<answer>



It's rare to see that,but I have seen some people use it.  Joan Baez and her daughter do.



</answer>

<question from>



Poyzin
Member since: 30 October 2008
Total points: 75 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



I need help on a hypothetical but very plausible life threatening situation that could happen to me?



Please don't laugh at me. I am not good at handling dangerous situations, and am lucky i have even survived this cruel world this long... LOL



But, here is the scenerio.



I live in an apartment and there are two locked doors i need to unlock to get into my apartment - an external one, and my own.  I also like to go for walks but live in a cold climate and winter is coming soon.



What if i go for a walk in winter and forget my keys? I would be locked outside, and when it gets dark, i could freeze to death.  The rental office closes at 6 pm and is not open at all on weekends.  Suppose i forget my cell phone too, which is likely because i almost never carry it. And since i forgot my keys, i couldn't go in my car and turn on the heater either.
Even if someone comes by and lets me into the first door, i would still be locked out and would have to sleep in the hallway.



How can i make sure this doesnt happen?  would i have to climb 40 feet up somehow and smash my way into my balcony door?



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



You have alot of time on your hands don't you?



</answer>

</category>



<question from>



Miscella...
Member since: 15 December 2007
Total points: 12 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Does anybody oher than me truly think that people suck and that they REALLY should not ponder upon.....?



what poeple are?



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



If you mean why bother, that's a philosophical question.  I assume, since you are also "people," you believe you too suck.



The idea is to reduce your own suckiness enough to entertain the thoughts about the real nature of people. Then you can better understand them and so, better understand yourself.



Good luck.  It's more difficult than it sounds.  The greatest problem is to reduce your own suckiness enough to see anything.  Then wading through the world full of philosophical crap that's been vomited onto the earth from universities is real drudgery.



Try starting with social institutions.  I landed there after wading through most religious and political philosophies and not finding much.



Examining the institutions answered a lot.



I'll give you a hint.  If you take off all your clothes and look in a mirror you will see just one of the many species of animals here on this earth.  It acts just like the others but it plays somewhat sophisticated games to avoid admitting that.



</answer>

You see how the whole picture can change if you hold it in a different light?
I think the picture I have is quite beautiful.

<original file>22518.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk113328.txt</current file name>




<category>



Society & Culture



Other - Society & Culture



</category>



<question from>



WTFBBQSA...
Member since: 05 July 2008
Total points: 208 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Why are some people so easily influenced by propaganda?



Sometimes just watching a silly commercial changes someone's opinion on a very important matter.



How can some people be so ignorant?



</question>



<answer from>



C S
Member since: 19 September 2008
Total points: 702 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



There's a wide range of people, between the extremely closed-minded (who never change their beliefs, no matter what evidence) to the too-open-minded (who change their beliefs every time any even half-plausible evidence pops up). The difference between them is that the closed-minded people are completely confident in their beliefs and don't even examine new evidence, while the gullible trust others' as much as or more than themselves, and take too many arguments as facts.



Think back to childhood or think of a child you know. Children often happily go with anything they are told to, because they do not tend to analyze whether or not something is actual evidence or not, and because they believe that adults know best. Or, children can be insanely stubborn, refusing to even hear arguments to the contrary. It's not a matter of intelligence, but some people never learn to trust their own judgment or to filter fact from fiction.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Great response



</asker's comment>



<comments>



WTFBBQSA…



Stef- I am not a Mccain supporter, an Obama supporter rather.



Mccain is the candidate that used propaganda to pick up a majority of his votes.



</comments>



<answer from>



hmmm
Member since: 01 June 2006
Total points: 1170 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



It's scary, but I think it has to do with how people are raised. If you aren't raised with anything to compare what you see on television etc. to, if you aren't getting your information from different sources and exploring what's out there, you're not going to have any sense of what's true and what isn't. Kids who are raised by a television set, or who get all of their news from MySpace, and adults who get all of their ballot information from campaign commercials and so on, aren't grounded in any kind of reality. You need a good, well-rounded education and reliable sources, with differing opinions to be less easily influenced.



</answer>



<answer from>



stef
Member since: 28 March 2006
Total points: 3979 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>

I have opinions some are quite strong but if someone can show me a better way or side to things then I will not let my education hold me back from changing an opinion.



Perhaps you are a McCain supporter and after all the advertising by the Obama team are annoyed that Obama has won.



</answer>

<question>



In 2007, what does it mean to be a “real” man?



For more information about my question, read the Answers blog: http://uk.blog.360.yahoo.com/blog-qT1KKP...



</question>



<answer from>



rockgirl...
Member since: 24 April 2006
Total points: 1645 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



I think being a real man is when you are yourself, and you are who you are, You take care of your business.



My husband is a real man, he takes care of his family, and he is the same man he was when i first met him, he is genuine.... He is not all about money, or how to get ahead in life, he is a simple man, and that is what makes him my man....



He will not tell someone what they want to hear just because they want to hear it, and he cant say the truth...



He is also just honest, and self less, always thinking of others, he thinks about me and my children before himself, he lives for us... I live for him to dont get me wrong, but he always treats me right, and tells me that he will do what ever he has to, as to survive in thisworld with his family, he doesnt care about going out to a party, or making new friends, he rules his life, and he will tell you his life is his family...



A true man takes care of his family.



Good question, i could go on forever about it.



</answer>

<answer from>



Future Citizen of Forvik
Member since: 05 December 2006
Total points: 19696 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



In 2007 the basic requirements of a real man haven't changed that much from 1900s CE or 2000 BCE.  We have to be able to provide for our families, be able to defend them from dangers, and provide a stable environment in which to raise our children.  A real man maintains good relationships with others.  Good standing in the community is often part of this, but a real man has to know when and where to  make a stand for his principals even if this goes against the norms.  A real man is not pushed around, is not a wimp, and doesn't whine or complain about things that he cannot change.  I am a Christian so I would also say that a real man walks a good and holy Christian walk and strives to be all that Jesus wants him to be.  In short being a real man is a tough job that most of us mess up from time to time.



</answer>

<answer>



A real man can communicate, without being afraid to safely express himself!
A real man can ask for directions,when he is in unfamiliar territory!
A real man is not afraid to cry, and release his emotions, instead of 'bucking up'!
A real man can allow a woman to open the door for him as a return courtesy!
A real man is smart enough to ask me what I want, instead of trying to be a mind-reader!
A real man can treat a Lady like a lady, and treat a woman like a Woman, being loving, but aggressive, but not abusive!
There is a difference! A vast difference!



A real man can be a companion during the day, company during the evening, and a lover in the  bedroom!
Every man can be a real man, it just takes practice!



</answer>



<answer from>



enzuigir...
Member since: 15 August 2006
Total points: 3489 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



To me being a real man is as follows



a) to provide, love and care for my family and friends
b) to treat people with the respect they deserve and which I would expect from them
c) to be honest in my life and to demand honesty from others
d) to keep to my own morality and not allow the world around me to drag me down to its level



The old image of a 'real man' as a hard drinking, wife beating, fighting, foul mouthed individual is dead.  The reality is that it never was an image to follow, merely an excuse for those who were like that.



In the modern world it is important (and sadly neglected) to be empathetic towards others and to work together to make life better for all those around us if we can.  Life is too short and too difficult to have to deal with all that macho, posturing rubbish.



</answer>

<question from>



Rose M
Member since: 02 July 2007

</question from>



<question>



Is this a good speech people i need opinions !!?



this is a speech that i wrote tell me what you think of it ...



FINALLY! A CHANGE HAS BEEN MADE FOR WE AMERICANS CAN NOW HAVE PEACE!! THE BUSH ADMINISTRATION IS OVER!!. MCCAIN'S ELECTION FOR PRESIDENT COULD HAVE CONTINUED THE CORRUPT ADMINISTRATION THAT HAS KILLED TENS OF THOUSANDS OF PEOPLE IN IRAQ. I M FOR OBAMA NOT BECAUSE OF HIS SKIN COLOR......... BECAUSE THE MAN WANTS TO CHANGE THINGS FOR THE BETTER, HE WANTS THE CORRUPTION TO STOP ! HE WANTS US AMERICANS TO BE AS ONE AND ITS IS OBVIOUS THAT WE AREN'T AS ONE. I WANT TO BE AS ONE ......I WANT CHANGE ........ AND NOW WE HAVE A CHANCE TO BECOME A BETTER COUNTRY AND A CHANCE TO BECOME BETTER PEOPLE FOR HE WILL SET A GOOD EXAMPLE FOR ALL OF US AS OUR PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES. THIS IS MY TRUTH THIS IS MY SPEECH........ I AM FOR BARACK OBAMA A MAN THAT WANTS CHANGE AND TO BE AS ONE.



By Rose Cino



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



I am trying to look at your speech objectively so that I might give you some constructive criticism. In general I see this as a statement not a speech, or it might make a good answer to an essay question. I suggest you read a few books on public speaking to understand the structure of a speech.



Get rid of the second and the third sentence. Your speech is about Barack Obama so why talk about anyone else.  In the fifth sentence use either "Us" or "Americans" also there seems to be something missing perhaps the phrase "He wants the American people to be united as one..."
If I were grading this I would give it a "C". A good effort but it needs work.



</answer>

Other - Society & Culture

<answer>



First, there is nothing wrong with putting deodorant on a child.  If they stink, they stink.  There is nothing wrong with that.



As far as cell phones go....



I dont have a land line, most of my friends dont have land lines, pay phones are all but gone, and I do NOT want my child going up to a stranger to ask for help.  I am sorry you dont understand that, but times have changed.  I get that 50 years ago people didnt have cell phones, but 50 years ago almost everyone had a land line, there were pay phones on every corner, and it was more or less safe for your child to ask the nearest adult for help.  Those things are NOT true anymore.



And I am not sure why you are comparing cell phones to head phones, but the only danger with head phones is playing them too loud.  Played at a normal level, they are fine.  There is no medical or scientific proof that cell phones cause cancer, if thats what you are talking about.



</answer>

<question from>



streetle...
Member since: 23 October 2008
Total points: 160 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Do you think legalizing Marijuana would benefit our economy?



Yes or no?



</question>



<answer from>



Ms. Opinionative
Member since: 28 March 2008
Total points: 14979 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Fashion & Accessories



Other - Society & Culture



</answer from>



<answer>



I'm sure it would. If weed got into stores, a bunch of loser potheads would spend their money on it, and it would be perfect for companies to make a profit. That's my view, but I wouldn't recommend making weed legal.



To AdamS: Well, that's my opinion. It's simple as that. You can't say it's a FACT they aren't losers.



</answer>



<answer from>



AdamS
Member since: 21 September 2008
Total points: 311 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes.



First of all. People who smoke marijuana aren't 'loser potheads' as put by that person above.



Anyway...if marijuana was legalized it would be really cheap. There goes profit for gangs (most of which make their money selling weed).



Also, if it could be sold legit without added chemicals like cigarettes then there would be another choice for people rather than alcohol. Alcohol is far worse for the body, and is addictive. Marijuana is not physically addictive.



Anyway. This is beyond yes or no. Haha.



In short - Yes.



</answer>



<answer from>



BOBA FETT
Member since: 26 October 2008
Total points: 990 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Maybe but I doubt it. If pot were legal it could be taxed but we'd lose tax revenue from alcohol, tobacco and pharmaceuticals if legal pot usage made a dent in their sales -- and it almost certainly would. Another factor is that marijuana is easy & cheap to grow -- it's said that pot is the biggest cash crop in California -- and I'd expect home cultivation to expand dramatically if legalized. This is why pot is illegal. The powers-that-be don't want people producing their own drugs any more than OPEC wants you to produce your own energy. There are good reasons to legalize pot but I don't think benefiting the economy is one of them.



</answer>



<answer from>



sitnbitc...
Member since: 14 July 2007
Total points: 129 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Of course. Weed should be legal. It is harmless. except to your grocery bill.



</answer>



<answer from>



Frankie S
Member since: 01 November 2008

<question>



Should you argue with people who you know to be dead wrong?



Like when you hear someone say something you know is totally wrong but you also know that if you contradict their point of view they'll only end up defending their opinion (which they think is the absolute truth) and because their sense of self-importance is damaged they'll then try and put you down by attempting to prove that you're non compos mentis and do what you will, they'll never come around to your way of thinking because their pride is so precious to them. So what do you do when you get in a situation like that? What is the best thing to do when someone says that America is not a democracy, Obama is a moron or Putin is just a prime-minister who cares for his country and other bullshit like that? I mean how do you react? What if your teacher is wrong and he doesn't know one hoot about politics but makes some unreasonable statements, do you tell them they're wrong? ... 'Cause from my point of view it all seems kind of futile to try to prove people they're wrong. It knda makes me think... should you argue with anyone? I mean what's the point? And the same thing with everything else - politics, religion or what kind of clothes you should wear or how you should live... What's the point in even telling others what you think if you know that'll only ignite disagreement and lead to an argument, that most likely won't solve anything? So what should I do in cases like this? Should I tell people what I think when they're feeding me some of their BS?



</question>

Sudz

<answer>



The point is when you believe, think, or know you are right.  The right answer may just be dependent on it being the right answer for you.  No one can tell you who to vote for, or not, what to wear, or even who to date and be friends with.  It is only debatable if the person is questioning his or her choices.  Then and only then, is it a debate.  Usually, if someone is firm even if they are firmly incorrect in you opinion then you can only state your opinion whether that opinion comes from your own personal experiences or it comes from something is full of proof.  The fact is that no one likes a know-it-all in certain social circles but it really works out in other circumstances where knowledge is valued.  Keep on giving your opinion because for what it is worth, you can have a impact on the lives of people, now whether they take it negatively or positively is up to them.



</answer>

<answer>



The Australians follow the USA in placing the day of the month after the month -- today, for example being 11/5/08 in those countries, whereas elsewhere in the world it's 5/11/08.



Otherwise, look for examples in music, in fashion, in social mores, where the American lead seems to be followed, largely through the influence of TV. The Australian soap operas bear much resemblance to those of the USA.

<answer>



Plato



</answer>



<answer from>



No N
Member since: 01 July 2008
Total points: 248 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>

</answer>



<answer from>



I wonder
Member since: 29 October 2008
Total points: 260 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



•On the question of chronology, two external references are helpful:



Aristotle tells us that the Laws is later than the Republic, (Pol. 2.6) and



Diogenes Laertius (3.37) reports that it was unfinished at Plato's death (and the text of the Laws itself shows some signs of incompleteness and lack of revision).[2]



Platonic scholars also frequently appeal to stylometry (that is, the quantitative study of the features of Plato's prose style) to help to date the dialogues. Although the usefulness of stylometry is sometimes questioned, it is widely accepted and the agreement of many such studies allows us to divide the dialogues, with some confidence, into three groups.[3]



Group 3: Critias, Laws, Philebus, Sophist, Statesman, and Timaeus



Group 2: Parmenides, Phaedrus, Republic, and Theaetetus



Group 1: the rest



Drawing upon other evidence, it is reasonable to see the dialogues in Group 3 as the latest. Given the length of the Laws (it is the longest of the dialogues and is, roughly 20% longer than the Republic), it seems likely that its composition overlapped with the composition of at least some of the other dialogues in Group 3.



2. The Laws’ Relation to the Republic
The Laws comprises a conversation in 12 books, set on Crete, among three interlocutors: an unnamed Athenian Visitor (Plato's spokesman in the Laws), Megillus, a Spartan, and, Kleinias, a Cretan. The first two books consider what the proper goal or end (telos) of legislation is. Plato claims that even the best of extant constitutions, such as those of Crete and Sparta, have gone wrong on this crucial point. In all his legislation, the lawgiver must aim at a single goal and that is virtue. In particular, the lawgiver must aim at fostering all the virtues -- courage, justice, moderation, and wisdom -- in the citizens as a whole (Laws 630C3-6, 705D3-706A4).[4] So if Plato is to meet his own criterion for a good city, the rest of the Laws should show how the constitution (politeia) of this city reliably produces citizens who genuinely possess all the virtues.



At the end of Book 3 (Laws 702BD), Kleinias announces that the cities of Crete have decided to found a new city, to be named Magnesia, in a long abandoned part of Crete and they have given the responsibility for doing so to his city, Knossos, and that Knossos has delegated this authority to himself and nine others. He asks the Athenian to help in the construction of the new city's constitution and laws. In Books 4-12, the Athenian sketches, often in considerable detail, the constitution, the political and social institutions, and the laws of this new city, along with the political and ethical principles that justify them.



Since both the Republic and the Laws involve the creation of a good city, discussion of topics in political theory as well as related ethical and psychological material, it is natural to ask what the relation between the two dialogues is. The predominant view, until fairly recently, holds that the Republic is Plato's statement of what the ideally best city is; the Laws, on the other hand, describes the city that would be best, given less optimistic assumptions about what human nature is capable of. This position has two variants, depending on one's view of whether Plato at the time of the Republic thought that its political program was compatible with human nature. If one thinks that even at the time of the Republic, Plato thought that its ideal city placed too great demands on its citizens to be psychologically realizable, then one can hold that the Laws is entirely consistent with the Republic: they could, at least as far as their philosophical positions are concerned, have been written at the same time.[5] If, on the other hand, one thinks that Plato held that the city of the Republic was psychologically possible, even if difficult to realize, it is natural to see the Laws as the outcome of a change in Plato's views about human nature.[6] The first view faces two challenges:



providing evidence from the Republic that Plato did not think its ideal city was realizable, and



either explaining why the Republic does not at least gesture in the direction of the arrangements of the Laws as the best humanly possible option or arguing that we can find such evidence.



The second view should explain why Plato becomes more pessimistic about human nature. The need for such an explanation is especially pressing, since the most common attempt to do so by appealing to Plato's experiences in Sicily is philosophically quite unsatisfactory.[7]



In recent years, it has been argued that there are deep and pervasive differences between the Republic and the Laws (and more generally between the dialogues of Group 3 and those of Group 2) on ethical and political questions.[8] The debate over these claims is just in its initial stages and no scholarly consensus has yet emerged. Given this state of flux, the rest of this entry sketches a few important topics of contempor



</answer>



<answer from>



Edward
Member since: 27 June 2008
Total points: 143 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



This book might help: Plato's Ethics by Terence Irwin



"This exceptional book examines and explains Plato's answer to the normative question, "How ought we to live?" It discusses Plato's conception of the virtues; his views about the connection between the virtues and happiness; and the account of reason, desire, and motivation that underlies his arguments about the virtues. Plato's answer to the epistemological question, "How can we know how we ought to live?" is also discussed. His views on knowledge, belief, and inquiry, and his theory of Forms, are examined, insofar as they are relevant to his ethical view. Terence Irwin traces the development of Plato's moral philosophy, from the Socratic dialogues to its fullest exposition in the Republic. Plato's Ethics discusses Plato's reasons for abandoning or modifying some aspects of Socratic ethics, and for believing that he preserves Socrates' essential insights. A brief and selective discussion of the Statesmen, Philebus, and Laws is included."



Source(s):



http://www.amazon.com/Platos-Ethics-Tere...



</answer>

<question from>



Lizz S
Member since: 27 October 2008
Total points: 470 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



What do people know about Guy fawkes?



I was Just wondering what people know about him that's all.



Fact etc
Thank you xx



</question>



<answer from>



L M
Member since: 10 October 2008
Total points: 347 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



didn't he no plot to blow up the houses of Parliament or something but it didn't work....or did it cant remember



</answer>



<answer from>



Damien D
Member since: 26 October 2008
Total points: 173 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



He wasnt the actual 'plotter' so to speak, he was given the duty to carry out the plot. They were going to blow up the parliament in protest to the aristocrats of England during the State Opening of Parliament. When asked what he intended to with so much gunpowder, he replied "to blow you scotch beggars back to your own native mountains!" Cool dude, symbol of anarchy, popular due to many movies, poems and other works of literature with themes that are related to him. Plus there are "Guy Fawkes" masks, which are a representation of a popular caricature of him, seen on the movie 'V for Vendetta'



</answer>

<question>



Ethnicity question and DNA testing?

I know that it is hard to tell the ethnic background of someone by looking.

But I would appreciate your opinion, if you wouldn't mind.

and something else.

<answer>



I would say probably Middle Eastern or African.  I am melungeon, which means I look white with olive skin (some people think I'm Iranian, some people think I'm Hispanic, some people think I'm Greek), but I'm actually a mix of Black, White, Native American, and Middle Eastern.

Arggg

<answer>



Native American?

<question from>



Laughing all the way
Member since: 25 August 2007
Total points: 4386 (Level 4)



</question from>



<question>



How do I stop sucking at life?



I've always sucked at life. I'm in my first semester of university and If I'm not already I will soon be an academic joke. I don't have very many friends, I think my roommate might hate me and I don't know why. I am a good roommate, I don't touch her stuff and I keep my side of the room clean, I vacuum once a week, and I buy the air fresheners and febreeze. So it must be my personality. I lost my room key, my key chain had a clip and the clip fell off. I don't even have a key anymore and I looked everywhere for it and I can't find it. I'm supposed to be doing homework but I can't find an academic journal to discuss my problem of my chosen environmental issue small scale litter.



I am a major procrastinator and I would like to stop it but I can't. I have ADD and even my meds don't seem to be helping anymore. And last but not least I am as stupid as a doormat. Is there any way to improve intelligence? How are you guys good at life? Do you have any tips for someone who sucks at it?



</question>



<answer from>



Mike G
Member since: 30 June 2008
Total points: 293 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



You have taken the first two steps in helping yourself. The first is recognizing that you need help and the second is asking for help. Organization is one of the keys to success. If you have what you need when you need it you keep your stress down and you are able to make decisions. Another part is taking time to think before you react. Think about about the possible outcomes and make informed decisions. Being prepared also goes along with organization and success. If you are able to prepare before you go to class or work then you more often then not have success.



As far as the roommate goes you might want to ask her what is the matter. After all you have to live together might as well make the best of it.



</answer>



<answer from>



Dr.ShowT...
Member since: 26 August 2008
Total points: 117 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Just open up to the right people i had friends with ADD and we got along just fine.



</answer>

Please don't point that thing at us, it's very offensive, and what does it say about YOU?



</answer>

<question>



When people debate, is the one who talks the loudest perceived as the victor of that debate?



Or is it that the one who talks the most subtly, but too with the most sense and logic, wins?



</question>



<answer from>



Joe P
Member since: 01 July 2008
Total points: 1448 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



You described the Democrats (loud).And the republicans Conservative.Hope I helped.



</answer>



<answer from>



Deity of Peace
Member since: 19 September 2007
Total points: 7045 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Not really. In their mind they're winning the debate. They figure that if they're the only one being heard then they're right (because they're getting their point across). But in all actuality, they make themselves look like "buffoons" and childish, because they're not adult enough to engage in a sensible conversation. You can agree to disagree with someone and still be civil about it, but most people fail to grasp this concept. I don't waste my time debating with people like this, because you'll never get anywhere with them. In their mind they're right, and everyone (that can't be heard) is wrong.



</answer>



<answer from>



Dr.ShowT...
Member since: 26 August 2008
Total points: 123 (Level 1)



</answer from>

<question from>



Agent Scully

</question from>



<question>



Do you still watch tv, what shows?



I have a big problem with tv - what I like is on when I am at work, the rerun is at 5-6 in the morning, or its on weekends when I am out. Or if I like something and is on at decent hours like 8,9 in the evening, then obviously 2-3 other just as interesting things will be on at the very same time.
Tv is just frustrating...
And obviously others feels thisway too, this is why youtube exists.
Why is tv programming so lousy, bad hours, bad shows at good hours, total disrespect for the viewers?



</question>



<answer from>



SouthBay
Member since: 30 June 2008
Total points: 116 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Because they want you up for more advertising.  The hallmark of their existance.  Without advertising commercial T.V. would not exist.
Companies pay BIG BUCKS for air time and want as many buyers as possible viewing their sales pitch.  So, the most popular shows are scheduled later to insure a larger viewing audience.
It all comes down to $$$$$



Source(s):



16 years in the Adv/Marketing field



</answer>



<answer from>



MM9
Member since: 13 September 2007
Total points: 507 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



You could just set-up a VCR or something to record the shows you want to watch, then just watch them when you get home and all the lame TV is on.  Then you could just do it again the next day.



Source(s):



What I do most of the week.



</answer>

<question>



How are there so many porn stars in the world?



Type in "porn" or "XXX" into a search engine, and you get over 400 million porn entries. Each one of those sites has 1000-10,000 images.



Now, two things you'll notice about all porn images



1. every woman is extremely attractive



2. You never see a duplicate woman



If there is 400 million porn sites, each with 1000-10,000 images, that means there has to be 400 billion female porn stars in the world!!! Even if you take a conservative estimate and say that most of those porn sites are duplicates, there would still have to be well over a half a billion porn stars to account for all that porn.



If there is 6.6 billion people on earth, let's say half are woman, then the pool of women is 3.3. billion. Out of that number, only a small percentage is young enough to be in porn, a smaller percentage of that is attractive enough to be in porn, and an even smaller percentage of that would even want to be in porn. It is remarkable that there is even a million or ten million female porn stars, but a billion or more???



Question, how often do you actually see an attractive women on the street who has starred in a porn?



And why, with the exception of famous porn stars like Jenna Jameson and others, do you never see a duplicate in the millions of porn images on the website???



What the bleep is going on here???



</question>

She is just trashy.

<answer>



This is a manager's job;  he/she needs to sit everyone down and explain the rules, and make sure they are enforced.



You are doing the grown-up thing by still being nice despite miss attitude, and that is important.  You don't want to be dragged into any arguments, and the best way not to is to avoid taking this girl's bait.  You should remain professional as you are.



I would have a private discussion about this with your manager.  Proper attire and customer courtesy should be enforced with an iron hand or you are going to lose customers, and the business's reputation will be affected.  If the business had a dress code, no employee can dispute it and say "It's professionl attire to me."



You could also do the co-worker grading and make everyone aware that they are being graded so to speak, by their co-workers.  Anyone who gets a low grade is going to have to have a little chat with the manager to clean it up, or risk losing their job.



She sounds black, and lots of black women tend to have attitude; for better or for worse.  (yes I know, it sounds racist, but I have been around a lot of black women and they even admit this.)  This isn't going to go away, but she does need to figure out when it's apropriate to use it, and when it's not.



As far as the spelling, well, you need to pick your battles.  It is necessary for her job?  Is she writing speeches for the president, or just leaving sticky notes?



Anyways, keep up your professionalism, and have a chat with the manager and suggest an employee meeting where all the rules are talked about and how they will be enforced.



</answer>

<question from>



Jane d
Member since: 10 September 2007
Total points: 957 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



Orientalism? what is that?



can someone provide an example?



</question>



<answer from>



chrysost...
Member since: 26 May 2008
Total points: 1813 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Largely speaking its how the west views the Orient (the east). The west is the Occident.



Edward Said wrote a book called "Orientalism" in which he tried to show that the Western writers are 'biased' (everyone is biased so it's no major news of his). The extension of this is that Westerners don't attribute all the debt we're supposed to owe the East (read "Islam") for our civilization. It's a means of preventing ciritique of Islam - as any criticisim of Islam is inherently 'biased', therefore not worth reading.



It's very popular theory amongst a certain age-group of historians. It's reflected in popular movies such as "Kingdom of Heaven"



The book has been answered already with "Defending the West: A Critique of Edward Said's Orientalism"; a book written by Ibn Warraq.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thanks :)



</asker's comment>

<question from>



Andrew
Member since: 08 March 2007
Total points: 444 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



What is YOUR opinion on reverse-racism?



Let me clarify a little bit. Reverse-racism is where, to kind of apologize for the previous cruel racist status of white people, certain minorities get a huge bonus on their taxes and great scholarship opportunities.



I personally don't think this is right, because reverse-racism is actually being racist to while people now. I don't think the modern world should be "an eye for an eye".



I'm a believer that BET is a great channel for great comforts, but if there was a WET, it would but shut off after a day.



Here is an exact quote from somebody here on Yahoo "I mean we all know that most white people don't need scholarships like this because most of the time they already have money to pay for college but most blacks on the other hand have it harder because they just don't have the money so it makes sense that we have scholarships and you guys don't"



That does not make ANY sense to me. I have friends who have single parents, who work at stores like McDonald's and can't get a better job. They can't even pay for college. I know more white people like that than Blacks, or Hispanics.



My overall Opinion: make it actually EQUAL. Everybody in the world (well, usually) is a great mix of different races, where probably some in the mix were enslaved, mistreated, etc. I do not want a WET or anything, but why are we in the mindset that blacks can praise themselves but white people cannot? Trust us, we need the money.



Please tell me your opinion, even if its different from mine, so I can get a few ideas. I plan to go far with this.



</question>



<answer from>



Gus S
Member since: 29 May 2008
Total points: 3046 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



The term "reverse-racism" is, itself, racist because it implies that the definition of racism is: "A white person hating someone of another race". This assumption is absurd. I actually heard a black woman, who was a member of the NAACP ("NAACP" is also a racist acronym), who said that white people are genetically predisposed to racism! We're genetically racist?! Genetically racist! What the hell kind of f*cking ridiculous junk science is that?!?!



</answer>



<answer from>



Kimberly M
Member since: 27 July 2008
Total points: 1088 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Andrew, i see what you're saying. You are talking about affirmative action in essence. I do agree with you for the most part, but somehow a little bit I don't. I don't think people should be bending over backwards now to help minorities but on some levels I feel like sometimes they need a little extra help depending on the situation. While I was in sociology I learned that the average white male high school graduate makes more money in his life time than the Latina college graduate. That really isn't fair. I don't know, it is a really sticky issue. There was an affirmative action group on my college campus and all the member were hassling me to join just because I am black. When I said I didn't want to, I was looked down upon. So basically what I am I saying? I don't know. You do raise a very good point though. Life isn't fair. this is one of those occasions where life is more unfair and cruel to white people. Also I see what you're saying with BET. Black people created a channel like this (though it is now white owned) because there was little or no Black representation of our interest or desires in the media. The overall media and TV setup at the time, and for the most part currently, was catering to the Anglo-Saxon white majority. Now things are changing, and white people are not the majority in California but that still might not be represented in the media. I just want to say that I get what you're saying. I have white friends and they tell me the same thing. We get into friendly arguments because we don't agree but both parties can for the most part understand where the other is coming from.



</answer>



<answer from>



Jebus Saves
Member since: 16 July 2008
Total points: 189 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Because a high portion of the minority populace is poor. Its is demned equitable if more assistance goes that way. Is it right. . . No! equality is equality.  But the squeaky wheel gets the grease.



</answer>

<question from>



princill...
Member since: 19 December 2007
Total points: 2561 (Level 4)



</question from>



<question>



How can a person become more acceptance of who they are?



I know how hard it is to have everyone tell you what you are, who your not and what you can and can't do. How can a person be more open to accept that they can not be a people pleaser or a friend to everyone all while tiring to find themselves or figure out who they really are?



</question>



<answer from>



RosieRed
Member since: 06 June 2008
Total points: 1888 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Well, first -- look at THEM. Most of the time, people who spend all their time telling others what to do have plenty of issues of their own. If someone says, "you're this or that" or you need to do this or that -- don't automatically start listening to them and thinking, "hey.... maybe they're right... " They probably can't figure out their own life, so don't let them manage yours.  You just need practice making your own decisions on your own and sticking to them. Then, over time you'll get more secure and when people tell you to do things -- you might, if you think it's a good idea or you might just say, "uh, no -- I'm happy doing what I'm doing"  - but either way YOU'LL be making the decision :-)



</answer>



<asker's comment>



I completly agree.



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Nathan
Member since: 03 March 2008
Total points: 926 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



We could all write an essay on this subject.



I think its a matter of being more selfish to some degree - I sometimes got bad reactions from people when too eager to please. It needs a change in your mindset. Society isn't perfect so you can't expect that from yourself.



</answer>



<answer from>



Bboy4Lif...
Member since: 30 September 2008
Total points: 114 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>

<question from>



xAmy-lee...
Member since: 19 September 2008
Total points: 169 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



What do you personally think I should do in this situation?



Before I got with my boyfriend, I knew he smoked canabis. I was unaware of how much but its beside the point. It has always given me a headache, I don't know why but the smell of it makes it feel like someones crushing my head with a vice.. Anyway.. I started smoking it as I wanted to see what it was like, and my headaches stopped.



BUT..



I did alot of thinking about it, and I knew I'd been brought up better. Therefore I just stopped before I got addicted and whatever. I then got my headaches back and also hated it even more.
I really dislike the fact that my boyfriend smokes it.. and that everytime we go out thats all the conversation as most of our friends smoke it too. They never used to, but obviously peer pressure gets the better of some!



I try not to seem grumpy when my boyfriend is smoking it, he has cut down alot but I just want more from him. My only reasons are because of my headaches and that its illegal. I've been brought up better to know that its wrong.



I've spoken to him about it, and he just says the same thing everytime, ''you dont love me for who I am'' or ''your forcing me to quit''.
I just want me and him to work, but I'm far too stubborn to just 'put up with it'.. And I know I can do better.



What do I do?



</question>



<additional details>



By doing better I meant someone who doesn't smoke drugs..



And I'm asking a question not asking for ******* bitchy comments.



</additional details>



<answer from>

<question from>

</question from>



<question>



Is war natural or is it a corruption? ?



Is it supposed to exist? even if its not in the form of colonizing each others countries would it still exist, if so why? explain what would the world be like if there wasn't any war?



</question>



<answer from>



Ryan M
Member since: 15 September 2008
Total points: 476 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



War appears to be very natural, our social mechanism has lead us to many wars and since every group of humans will never agree on one unity there will always be conflict.  Perhaps peace is a lie.



But I would say yes, it is natural.



</answer>



<answer from>



jimmy
Member since: 17 December 2007
Total points: 1438 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



It is a natural thing when you refer to it with the idea of colonization, but when it is just some dope that needs to prove to his daddy that he can do something while in the White house, then no, it is not natural or good. It is as corrupt as it carrupt can be



</answer>



<answer from>



Ms. Opinionative
Member since: 28 March 2008
Total points: 11165 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Fashion & Accessories



Other - Society & Culture



</answer from>



<answer>



The definition of 'war' is "the waging of armed conflict against an enemy," so therefore, it's natural whether armed or not. For instance, other animals like squirrels and birds would fight each other over territory, and that's a part of nature. The fact is we're smart and have more advanced technology to aid us in conflict, which is really no different than a regular fight, only nations are involved. It's animal nature to want to another for certain reasons.



</answer>

<question from>



Julian Karswell
Member since: 15 January 2008
Total points: 4058 (Level 4)



</question from>



<question>



Was Bob Marley really a rapist?



'When Rita Marley, in a recent interview, revealed that she had been raped by Marley during their marriage, I was forced to believe her. I believed her because she just could not be so stupid as to sully Marley's name with so heinous an infamy if it did not actually take place.'



http://www.jamaicaobserver.com/columns/h...



</question>



<answer from>



Deity of Peace
Member since: 19 September 2007
Total points: 7028 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Well, like any other marriage, we as outsiders never really know what goes on behind closed door between the two people involved. Many of us would like to think that Bob Marley (an advocate for peace) would not show us two faces.



But its always possible that she could be telling the truth. At times, fame, money, and an abundance of women can (and does) change a mans out look on life, and the difference between right and wrong. So honestly, we would never really know the truth (because we where not there).



Remember, there's a saying that goes there is three sides to every story; there's his side (which we'll never hear), her side, and what really happened. A persons perception of a situation can always have an affect on how the story is being told.



Edit: Cherry Pie, how old are you? You do understand that rape can take place between a man and his wife right? You do understand the concept of rape (meaning vaginal, anal, or oral penetration against some ones will; both male and female). I think you need to do some research on this subject matter prior to making uneducated comments. Think about this when you tell your husband you’re not in the mood and he still “takes him some” anyway. The more I read your comment the sillier and ridiculous you make yourself look to everyone here.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



By far the most sensible answer.



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



BobMarle...
Member since: 01 May 2008
Total points: 420 (Level 2)



</answer from>

Member since: 01 July 2007

<answer from>



cherry pie

<answer>



A few years ago when I was a young teen, my cousin had behavior problems and she was a prostitute. Her mother kicked her out of the house because grew tired of her, and she stayed with our family. Despite her going out having sex with random guys for money, she was like a big sister to me, and we always had a good time tonight. Well, during the night of April 28, I came home feeling upset and worried because of a fight I got into with a friend. My little sister was sleep, so I stayed up watching TV, still with that worried, shaky feeling. Also, during that night, when my mother tried talking to my cousin about the dangers of prostitution, they had a big argument. It woke up my little sister, and I was getting even more worried. I just had that feeling something really bad was going to happen. Then my cousin left the house when my mother told her not to. I remember, when she was leaving, I was crying when I begged her to stay, but she left anyways. Well, she didn't return home in a while, and we later discovered she was murdered by one of her costumers so he could rob and not pay her. It was a horrible year for everyone. I know it's just a coincidence, but it really did seem like I felt something bad was going to happen that night.



</answer>
