<question>



Is war natural or is it a corruption? ?



Is it supposed to exist? even if its not in the form of colonizing each others countries would it still exist, if so why? explain what would the world be like if there wasn't any war?



</question>



<answer from>



Ryan M
Member since: 15 September 2008
Total points: 476 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



War appears to be very natural, our social mechanism has lead us to many wars and since every group of humans will never agree on one unity there will always be conflict.  Perhaps peace is a lie.



But I would say yes, it is natural.



</answer>



<answer from>



jimmy
Member since: 17 December 2007
Total points: 1438 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



It is a natural thing when you refer to it with the idea of colonization, but when it is just some dope that needs to prove to his daddy that he can do something while in the White house, then no, it is not natural or good. It is as corrupt as it carrupt can be



</answer>



<answer from>



Ms. Opinionative
Member since: 28 March 2008
Total points: 11169 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Fashion & Accessories



Other - Society & Culture



</answer from>



<answer>



The definition of 'war' is "the waging of armed conflict against an enemy," so therefore, it's natural whether armed or not. For instance, other animals like squirrels and birds fight each other over territory, which is a part of nature. However, The fact is we're more intelligent and we have advanced technology to aid us in conflict, which is really no different than a regular fight, only with the addition of nations, aircraft, and artillery. It's not only human, but animal nature to have particular reasons to fight.



</answer>

<question>



A question about "African Americans"?



I was looking at a question and it asked why there is a month for "blacks, but not for whites." There were a lot of answers that said "There are eleven months out of the year for white people." I don't understand why some think that. I feel so hurt when they think they are treated bad and I know they have gone through a lot and still do. I want better for them, but I don't get why some of them feel whites are "over ruling them." I have never treated someone bad because of their race, and I feel that in the media there are equal whites and blacks, but I do feel their aren't has many other races.

<answer from>



Beverly Kimora
Member since: 17 September 2008
Total points: 360 (Level 2)

<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Are you in history or if you have ever been in history? If you have or are what race did you study the most?

I should also be a wearing hair extensions or a wig. And I should also be very promiscuous. And wear clothing that's either too small or too large for my body. I should not speak well or I should be receiving a bad education Well I'm neither of those things. And I don't fit those stereotypes!  Although I sometimes do wear large clothing because I suffer from bad self esteem and and poor self image of myself! I just don't know why!
And when people meet me they expect less of me and that's no what they get!
This is why I find stereotypes funny! Like Sarah Silverman! (I hope that I spelled her name correctly!)
And it's great that you don't judge people by the color of their skin! A lot of people do though! But they are not worth the effort!
Well have a great day!

Nobody opens their eyes and says "the jews got all the money" or "whites own the media", its all taught to you somehow, and this **** needs to stop if everybody truly wants to live in a multicultural/racial society.



Black history month is to celebrate the freedom of an unjust system after the confederacy, and has nothing to do with pride as alot of blacks would believe. Its not a time to walk around head-high and mighty if your black, its to honour the change that had to be made (abolishing racism, slavery and prejudice) to make a better country. And although lots of prejudice still exists today, black history month is to remember that although at one time an entire race was segregated, they are now a huge part of american history and what the country is today.



And just on a second note, don't feel bad for anything. Many many cultures and races were abused during the revolution/founding of america. Asians, irish, british, mexicans, blacks, everybody was treated badly at that time, racism was world-wide and accepted so its selfish for blacks to not acknowledge the suffering of other races in context to their own (is some african americans want compensation from white people for the slave trade, even though Mexico owned 65% of the WORLD pop of black slaves). It was government that enslaved races, using racism as a tool for division of civilians. Not one race controlling the other, that has -never- happened in american history, people need to get educated on where racism comes from and how it helps government keep their power.

<question>



Why do people judge based on what others say...?



Why do people judge others based on what other people say about that person instead of getting to know that person themself? I have only 2 real friend where I live at,everyone else either pretends to be my friend or hates me and don't even know me. My husband and I have been married for 9 years we have two boys and we always like to have fun and play around a lot. Sure we are serious when we have to be,but most of the time we are fun loving people who do not like to be angry all the time. I think people view me as being a stupid,immature adult. Just because I am an adult,does not mean I have to act all snooty and angry all the time. We only live life once,and I don't plan on spending the rest of my life being a mean and crabby person. It's not that I am just looking for friends,but I wish people would stop listening to others who talk bad about me,and get to know me themself  before passing judgment on me(even though one has no right to judge) do I have a right to feel that way? Shouldn't we live life to the fullest and have fun doing so?



</question>



<answer from>



Darwins Finch
Member since: 26 September 2008
Total points: 215 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Because people would rather take the easy way out rather than spend the time to get to know someone.  Although for much of evolutionary history this trait has survived in humans because for a majority of the time it works, the sad truth.



</answer>

Member since: 05 September 2006

Becstar7...
Member since: 01 October 2008
Total points: 106 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



One friend's dad made a really awkward and clumsy speech about their falling out a year earlier - it's not the time and place unless you're making a grovelling apology!  Another friend's best man dragged out his speech waaaaayyy too long and people were bored of in-jokes after 35 minutes.



We went to one friends' wedding who had horrible food, they hadn't tried it and it was really cheap and nasty.  Think about what people like - nothing too exotic.



The worst thing at ours was the best man disappeared off to check into his hotel and held up all the photos and so there were loads we had to miss and we were really rushed :(  I've forgiven him... just.  On three hours sleep, I was a bit stressy and snappy at that point, and I regret that - count to ten, nothing matters that much.



The best... people were relaxed and enjoying themselves... we relaxed and enjoyed ourselves...



I also have a couple of regrets about not inviting a couple of old friends who I felt hadn't made much effort with me for a while - in hindsight I should have just included them because we've started to be friends again now. Although there's one acquaintance who thought she should be there who still isn't speaking to me (!) and I definitely stick to my rule of not having anyone there that you don't want there.



My most important advice is, I know everyone says it and you think you've heard them, but SAVOUR EVERY SECOND. It's over before you know it, and as long as you've got some great photos to remind you of each stage of the day, you'll never forget it.



Source(s):



18 months ago



</answer>

<question>



How many puffs are in a cigarette.?

<answer from>



Jane
Member since: 15 April 2008
Total points: 2250 (Level 3)

Becstar7...
Member since: 01 October 2008
Total points: 110 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I don't think smokers are bad people UNTIL they inflict their habit on me.



I assume you are smoking near them for you to believe that to be the cause of their looks..? If I have to inhale your toxic air, then I will give you a filthy look, the same I would if someone let gas off near me.



Do what you like in your own home with willing companions (i.e. not children) but the moment your filthy (and stupid as you know it harms you) habit encroaches on my right to breathe fresh air, that's when I think you're being bad.



And that includes at train stations, in high streets, or right outside the door the building I'm trying to enter!!



But I'm not writing off smokers altogether, some are considerate and care about how their actions affect others - I'm talking about the mothers smoking over their own baby's buggy, or in the car with all the windows closed... or the man on the station platform standing upwind from me when I was stood there first.



Actually, this may come across as really wrong, but I'll chance my arm, but I always say to my husband (who smokes socially when drinking) that I see smoking as a weakness.  Addiction is letting something be in control of you rather than the other way around, and I hate thinking of him as a weak and pathetic person - I think he's very strong and determined, and I hate cigarettes for making him appear any less than that.



Educated people know better.



</answer>



<answer from>

Member since: 29 August 2007
Total points: 7928 (Level 5)

<question>



Why should there be more people in the world?



Can you think of reasons?



</question>



<answer from>



GabiNews
Member since: 04 September 2008
Total points: 876 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Negative. More people means more stress on our already stretched resources. More people means more carbon footprints which contribute to global warming, melting ice caps, and starving polar bears. More people means less food, less air, less space.  More people means more congestion, more wars.



</answer>

<question>



Don't you think the world can be a pretty great place?



If you think about it...Excluding all the global warming, crime, etc.  Like look at us all on yahoo answers, helping each other - all different people from different countries.
And then all the things that are being invented, and all the good going on in the world.



Anyway...
Just thought I had to share that with you :)



</question>



<additional details>



Thanks for answering, Taylor.
And that is pretty ironic, haha.
X



Yep, 梨花 - that's exactly what I mean! :)
Oh and by the way, my name is 花 - I'm not japanese though lol.
X



</additional details>



<answer from>
Member since: 20 September 2008
Total points: 597 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



yup i can, haha.



its when we stop concentrating on material things and all the crap thats going on in the world, and just take a big breath and appreciate everything that is good in our lives and just concentrate on them for a few precious moments. lately, theres been so many negative things going on that its hard to focus on any positive, so its good to sit down and look at all the small nice things, such as people from all over the world helping others on random stuff on the internet, haha.

<question from>



Jim Maryland
Member since: 31 January 2007
Total points: 14048 (Level 6)



</question from>



<question>



How would you deal with a school that prohibits unusual hair styles?



My 14 year old son is going through a phase where he is dying his hair (blue).  He has been doing this for a few weeks and hasn't had any problems at school related to his hair color.  Well last night he had my wife give him "liberty spikes".  This morning, he went to school but was stopped in the hall and sent to the front office to go home and "fix" his hair.  The principal's issue with the hair was that it was "too disruptive".  Now even though I don't care for the hair style (color or spikes), I don't care that the school discriminates on his individuality/expression.  I know plenty of the kids at his school have multiple piercings, tattoos, clothing taste, and other hair styles that many people would disagree with but are permitted to attend school with.



Would you push the issue with the school and if so, how would you proceed?



Oh, we're in central Maryland and it is a public high school.



</question>



<answer from>



Jane
Member since: 15 April 2008
Total points: 2251 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



I would ask to see any written rules concerning hair style, if they are there I would expect that they are vague and open to interpretation.



You could quite Simply say that this is discrimination and that your son should not have to "fix" his hair unless every pupil at that school has to have their hair its natural colour.



</answer>



<answer from>



indian_c...
Member since: 30 May 2008
Total points: 2106 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Well this is a tough question. Its a question about attitude. The first thing is the color of hair is more noticeable than other things as piercing or tattoos. First u can fix his hair and then ask the school that my son is asking why can't i have my own individuality. If u don't fix is hair now, it'll be a matter of disobedience. It can effect his future life. So handle this situation carefully.



</answer>



<answer from>



missvonn...
Member since: 20 February 2006
Total points: 203 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I teach college English.  I never cease to be amazed at how much energy public schools put into humiliating the students and how little they put into teaching them things such as how to communicate in a way that affords them the chance to be heard and to be respected.



People easily grow out of experimental fashion, but have a much harder time remediating for educational neglect in high school.  I think a little mention of going to the media on this might do the trick.  I have a son who is in his twenties now, and on this issue, I would go toe-to-toe with the principal.



</answer>

</answer from>



<answer>

<answer from>



Stephanie S
Member since: 07 April 2008
Total points: 3902 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



LMAO...Yup - it's called Guy Fawkes Day and its celebrated in England on November 5 (I think).



The effigy isn't burnt because he's Catholic - he's burnt because he was caught in the plot to blow Parliament up during the reign of King James I.  It was a conspiracy that was designed and almost carried out by primarily English Catholics.  Their reason for this was because they were severely penalized because of their Catholicism.



Yeah - life sucked for English Catholics (as well as Scots & especially Irish) for a long time, but the holiday is to celebrate the capture of Guy Fawkes (who, most likely was an unfortunate patsy) and the prevention of the attempted destruction of an important part of the English government (not JUST the monarchy).  If it makes you feel any better, my dear - James I was the son of Mary, Queen of Scots - who herself was Catholic (James was raised Protestant though).



Course in America - which some take this view - we celebrate a holiday that is associated with us taking land from native inhabitants on this continent (Thanksgiving).  So I guess it's all relative.



</answer>

<original file>9900.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk33529.txt</current file name>




<category>



Society & Culture



Other - Society & Culture



</category>



<question from>



bobbybab...
Member since: 30 December 2007
Total points: 88 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Which major city has a limited amount of windows in their buildings due to old tax regulations ?



i think its amsterdam but im not sure



</question>



<answer from>



Caicos Turkey
Member since: 23 September 2006
Total points: 104604 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Languages



Law & Ethics



Other - Society & Culture



</answer from>



<answer>



It may be Edinburgh.



In 1696, Britain introduced a tax on the number of windows in a house, which was believed to be a proxy for the size of the house and hence its value (Grinath, 1988). Clearly, the number of windows may be correlated with house value, but such a tax would place equal levies on homes with equal number of windows regardless of location or state of repair. The tax may also lead to underconsumption of windows. When homeowners attempted to replace windows with other methods of letting in air and light, the tax was expanded to include all other forms of ventilation. A whole row of houses was built in Edinburgh, without a single window in the bedroom storey of the homes. Other homeowners would stop-up windows and then reopen them after the assessor had been by their house. The Window Tax remained in effect well into the 1850's.



Source(s):



http://www.dcwatch.com/taxrev/taxres17.h...



</answer>



<answer from>



thebeerm...
Member since: 20 July 2007
Total points: 420 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



The Bank of Ireland in College Green Dublin Ireland had to block up all of it's windows due to the fact that the British Government introduced a Tax on windows.



Source(s):



virtualtourist.com



</answer>

Its an interesting question.  Some people you avoid just because they look dangerous or scummy.  Yet I know of a guy who can't help the fact that he is amazingly ugly, but is a really nice guy, honest, a good worker, etc.  But people do avoid him like the plague as you said.  I usually think beautiful people of either sex are unapproachable or hopelessly stuck on themselves and frankly most of the time that proves to be true, but then you also sometimes get people who are astoundingly beautiful (or handsome) and are actually very kind and unassuming.  Appearances do count, its biological, a large per-centage of our brain is dedicated to facial recognition and whats attractive and what isn't has origins in both biology (healthy looking-good, unhealthy-not) and cultural (fat is good in some cultures, thin in others).

<answer from>



Zee ~
Member since: 20 July 2008
Total points: 139 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



"Why does Canada not speak up?"

That's a good question. Indeed, Canada is certainly a peaceful country ... but what exactly do they do to promote that peace? Nothing. These days, Canada seems to be like an observer of the world. The Canadian government could speak up about many issues to the world, the Canadian government could help do something about genocide, but they don't. Why? Because like most western countries, they're only concerned about achieving more wealth and prosperity within their own nation. So long as Canada is prospering and there are no threats to Canada … their government really couldn’t be bothered to care about what’s going on in the rest of the world. These days, the closest a Canadian will get to "speaking up" is watching CNN and proudly boasting "Shame those Americans don't have "free" health care ... but we do!!"



</answer>

<question>



Why is the UK more expensive than USA



Ive converted all the prices to the US dollar as you can see

2 bedroom flat average
London $1,667
New York City $200

Petrol average
UK $10
USA $4

So guess your wages are lower than in the UK to even out the spending. So all your products must be very cheaper than ours. My friend who have been US to shop said everything is very cheap.

Why is this is it because the fact in the UK there as so many benefits for immigrants and the unemployed. If so why are there many ghettos in the US compared to the UK we must have some rich poor people.

<answer from>



Steve S
Member since: 01 July 2008
Total points: 524 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



First off, "Eleanor Rigby" has it all wrong. I know I shouldn't say that because, being an American, I couldn't possibly know anything, right? Do humor me. Several things are in play here:

a) Good luck trying to find anything for $200 in NY or anywhere else, rent control notwithstanding.

b) Fuel prices are as much a function of the economies of scale as anything else. From higher demand comes higher production, meaning a lower production cost per gallon. So too are the l taxes on fuel lower here (as a percentage) than in the UK. But before I read the latest diatribe about spoiled Americans, consider this; the average long-haul trip on the Continent is roughly 360 miles. I routinely truck 2,180 - ONE WAY. The adjusted price, seemingly near double in the UK, does not at all reflect the multiples of distance we face here. I live in Phoenix, Arizona. In a trip merely to my brother's house I'll drive 45 miles, also one way. And he lives in Phoenix metro too. In the militarty I used to drive from Heathrow to Holyloch. I'll take those distances any day, and at the UK fuel price, over what I shell out here at ours.

c) The broad social safety net Brits love to brag about costs money, and lots of it, aggravated further by the nature of any bureaucracy to waste it. Cool by me, but the higher prices typically found in the UK are a function of the much higher marginal rates Brits pay. Taxation is passed by business on to the consumer, and it can be no other way. In America we tend to be suspicious of the teeth-gritting love that is government. I share that suspicion, and would rather have my freedom and my earnings to spend as I like than live in a nanny state. We are citizens, not subjects; again, these are choices we all make.



d) The dollar, after years of being too high, is now much softer. This means that, at least for now, your money goes even farther here than it used to. "Eleanor" might take note of that. I hear New Jersey Wal-Marts are having a sale on e-large knickers.



</answer>



<answer from>



yo
Member since: 21 July 2006
Total points: 10619 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



BORN FREE TAXED TILL DEATH HERE

BUT YOUR ECONOMY IS IN A RIGHT STATE YOU ALL OWE SO MUCH CREDIT CRUNCH DOWN TO THE AMERICANS IM AFRAID BORROWING MORE THAN THEY HAVE CAUGHT UP WITH THEM PLENTY HERE IN DEBT  BUT YOU FAR OUTWEIGH THE BRITS ON MONEY OWED
NOW PLEASE SEND ME 20 PAIRS OF LEVIS HERES A FIVER WINK WINK SAY NO MORE 
PMSL

<answer from>



Deplorab...
Member since: 12 May 2008
Total points: 2496 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



I lost everything that I thought made "me" a number of years ago;
I lost my husband, marriage, children, family, home, farm, business...and I suffered from Fibromyalgia, Chronic Fatigue Syndrome, leftover nonsense from Cancer... I lost the will to live, yeah.



It was not so much that I wanted to die, as that I just didn't want to slog through the struggle of living. I'd get through one day, and then there would be a whole nuther one to get through. It was rough. It was exhausting.



At one point, I was attending a group function and the leader of the group passed around paper and crayons and told us to draw ourselves and our life. I just sat there, and after about ten minutes, I got up and walked out.

I kept going to my support group because, well, because they told me to. I just kept going. After about 6 wrenching, horrendous years of work, I had the stunning revelation one day that I had been the one chosen to go through this ghastly gawdawful atrocity because I am the one who can survive it. And more than survive it, I am the one who can go on to find peace and even happiness, and stand witness for those who come after me, who think that their situation is not survivable.



You are not fooling, I remember long days of sitting on a sofa, staring at the wall, unable to decide to even eat or get dressed. Thank goodness for my little cat, who I carried out of the holocaust in my arms, and thank goodness for those people who said, "See you tomorrow night"...wherever the  support group meeting was the next night, they made sure to gently remind me that I was wanted and needed there, and when and where to show up.



So not only is it possible to lose the will to live, it is possible to get it back, as well. Thank you for asking.



</answer>

<answer from>

</answer from>



<answer>



Over 22 and under 40.

Under 22 and most people have no idea what life is really like.  They're either too blinded by idealism or too heavily influenced by other people's opinions.  Personally, I'd say 25-28 is ideal.  Usually by this time, you've not only matured to a reasonable level, but you're more financially able to handle having a child.

Over 40 and there are serious health issues which only get worse as time goes on.  Yes, it's possible for women over 40 to have a child, but invariably those women spend tons of money on some aspect of their pregnancy that younger women do not.  Extra "high risk" testing, etc.

Too many young girls in today's society think that they're ready to have a baby just because they want one.  Not only is it stupid to think you can handle having a baby before you're even out of high school, but it puts undue pressure on the mother in the most emotionally turbulent decade of her life.



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>

<answer from>



blp2559
Member since: 17 January 2008
Total points: 2331 (Level 3)



Contributing In:



Singles & Dating



</answer from>



<answer>



A baby = forever. It means responsibility and growing up at a fast pace at a young age. Having sex before marriage is also a personal choice and, most of the time, only between the girl and her boy (hence I said "girl" and "boy" and not man and woman). But marriage means forever. It means something that you could possibly regret and want to change. Marriage is a sanctioned institution that is bound by law and God. At 17, you can choose to open your legs. You can choose to keep the being that is made by sex. But a 17 year old SHOULD be out having fun. Should be out doing things that you won't be able to do later. Being married holds you and constrains you to only a few things.



You have to put time and experience behind that big of a life choice. You have to have lots of time to think it over because it's a HUGE decision that you actually make. Having a baby at 17 is NOT planned. It happens and you live with it. That baby will make you feel so much more complete but being married means that you're stuck with that person (so to speak) forever.



Enjoy your younger years and don't worry about babies and a husband. It's, quite frankly, immature to be thinking that you can raise a family and live care-free for the rest of your life with a person that you don't REALLY know. Before getting married, you NEED to live with that person for at least a year. That way, you figure each other out. I know this sounds bad, but it's best to have sex before you get married aswell so you have a feel for if you could actually BE with this person every night for the rest of your life aswell.. Ok, I've talked enough about marriage and children, you have a good one hun.
-Later Gator-



</answer>



<answer from>



fire958p
Member since: 05 December 2006
Total points: 187 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Society doesn't think it is OK to have sex at seventeen or any age other then when the two people are responsible, MATURE, and aware of the consequences possible with their actions. But for the last 25 years sex has been in everyone's face so much, society is starting to get numb when responding to the challenge of warding off teenage pregnancy, AIDS, sexually transmitted diseases, and destroyed lives because of a few minutes of pleasure that the media and culture have turned into THE BIG DRIVE. Sex, love and marriage are never acceptable unless the people are mature and able to take full cognisant care of themselved AND the results.



</answer>

<question>



In 2007, what does it mean to be a “real” man?



For more information about my question, read the Answers blog: http://uk.blog.360.yahoo.com/blog-qT1KKP...



</question>



<answer from>



rockgirl...
Member since: 24 April 2006
Total points: 1609 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



I think being a real man is when you are yourself, and you are who you are, You take care of your business.

My husband is a real man, he takes care of his family, and he is the same man he was when i first met him, he is genuine.... He is not all about money, or how to get ahead in life, he is a simple man, and that is what makes him my man....

He will not tell someone what they want to hear just because they want to hear it, and he cant say the truth...

He is also just honest, and self less, always thinking of others, he thinks about me and my children before himself, he lives for us... I live for him to dont get me wrong, but he always treats me right, and tells me that he will do what ever he has to, as to survive in thisworld with his family, he doesnt care about going out to a party, or making new friends, he rules his life, and he will tell you his life is his family...

A true man takes care of his family.

Good question, i could go on forever about it.



</answer>

<answer>



In 2007 the basic requirements of a real man haven't changed that much from 1900s CE or 2000 BCE.  We have to be able to provide for our families, be able to defend them from dangers, and provide a stable environment in which to raise our children.  A real man maintains good relationships with others.  Good standing in the community is often part of this, but a real man has to know when and where to  make a stand for his principals even if this goes against the norms.  A real man is not pushed around, is not a wimp, and doesn't whine or complain about things that he cannot change.  I am a Christian so I would also say that a real man walks a good and holy Christian walk and strives to be all that Jesus wants him to be.  In short being a real man is a tough job that most of us mess up from time to time.



</answer>

<question from>



LadyMoon
Member since: 18 May 2008
Total points: 1457 (Level 3)



</question from>



<question>



Why are cheap, simple weddings "unacceptable" in the UK these days?



I first got married at 22 - in a registry office - and we spent no more than £300 on the whole thing.  People I knew were so shocked

"OH I could NEVER do that, my mum would be HEARTBROKEN, she really wants me to have a big white wedding" blah blah drone drone

I'm about to get married again - registry office again - and we're spending maybe £1,000 tops on it all.

And again - same shock and disgust from my colleagues - I actually have to lie and pretend that our wedding rings are costing more than they are because of the disgusted looks I'd get if I told them we're getting £50 ones from Argos, lol . . .one girl I work with boasted incessantly about how she wouldn't get engaged unless her bf got her a ring costing AT LEAST £3,000 . . .

Why the snobbery? Why does a wedding HAVE to cost £20,000 or its somehow not seen as meaningful or valid? God knows, precious few people get married in the UK these days - if it wasn't so "shameful" to do it cheaply more might be tempted.  From my experience, the cost alone puts a lot of people off the thought of marriage.

No wonder we're all up to our armpits in debt in this country



. . .



</question>



<additional details>



We're not even having a reception as we can't afford it and our "guests" (family and friends) will understand this.  We're just all going for a pub lunch afterward the ceremony.  Terribly sorry if that "offends" our "guests" - this is probably why we only invited close friends/family who would understand and just be happy we're getting married.  We aren't in the position of indulging greedy people who expect us to spoil them when we can't afford to.



Lol Caicos - going abroad, what with air fares etc is still really expensive!!!  I think you've missed my point.  Why can't people just be satisfied with the local registry office and a home-made buffet or meal afterwards?!  Like they used to!  When did getting married become something which has to cost £1,000s?



</additional details>



<answer from>



Rowan
Member since: 23 March 2006
Total points: 11756 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



They're not. It's just there are a lot of shallow people around which is why celeb mags sell so well. It has always been the case though. The majority of people don't spend an absolute fortune aas they can't afford it.



</answer>



<answer from>

Member since: 25 June 2008

i think it's the silly girls who read magazines who want a carbon copy wedding that hark on about expense

<answer>



I think that some of it has to do with the venue. If you choose somewhere very posh, guests assume that the reception will be equally grand. With the kind of prices you are discussing, I can see why so many people travel to the Caribbean for beach weddings. When all is said and done, you are not spending a fortune on the ceremony and the reception and you are right there on the spot for your honeymoon. People can come if they want to, but they pay their own way. I begin to like the idea more and more.



</answer>



<answer from>



world and all its' contents
Member since: 07 June 2008
Total points: 1709 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



I think your attitude is spot on. Why waste money on that you will need to buy and never use again, I understand dresses can cost up to £2-3,000 which is absurd. Plus bridesmaids. What do you do with these clothes after the 'big day'. Then you get sucked into the church and you pay to decorate it and then the reception. It seems fashionable to have the reception and the rest of the days frivolities in a grand house style hotel, where the guests can stay over night (at their expense) but what about the food at the reception, the drink and after all that there is another crowd arrive for the evening reception, DJ more booze and nibbles. Total cost, well not much change out of £30,000. If you have that sort of money and most of us don't, then you are better off using for yourselves in your new married live and not try and out do the previous wedding you went to. Good on yer!



</answer>

<question from>



Mackenzie Crook
Member since: 25 April 2008
Total points: 99 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



If you could get ten years' salary in a lump sum, how would you spend it and why?



Watch an exclusive clip of "Three And Out" here:

http://uk.movies.yahoo.com/t/Three-And-O...



</question>



<answer from>



gvih2g2
Member since: 14 August 2006
Total points: 8247 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



I did, when I sold my share in a software company to my partners and "retired" (at 35).

At first it was great - no mortgage or bills to worry about, a quiet life in the country with no commute, and I could act out my fantasy of being a writer for a couple of years and treat myself to a few things I'd always wanted - a sports car, a telescope, an expensive camera, a road-trip holiday through the USA.

But I got depressed (not badly enough to need medical treatment, but enough to stop me enjoying much of life). I got scared, obsessed with "protecting" the rest of the money - and as a result living more cheaply and less well than I had when I was working. I missed the buzz of work and the company of my colleagues.

I'm now back at work, still with no mortgage and no real money worries but with a family who help me spend any cash that's left :-), and in many ways it's almost as if I'd never had the money. I'm in a less-pressured job, but there's enough activity to still get that buzz, and it's great to be amongst people again. So be careful what you wish for!



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Amazing answer, thanks!



</asker's comment>

I would be able to support the couple of local charities I occasionally support a bit more and just relax and have money to do nice things with my daughter. <answer>



Depends what my salary was; if I get £10k annually, I'd use it to tie up some loose ends. Maybe I'd take a few years out to bike round Europe - I drew up the plans, then realised I really didn't have the means to do it. I might use it tide me over whilst attempting to edit my book and get it published, promote it, etc; the first draft was written in calmer and easier times. To publish is a hard dream to keep alive. These sorts of unfinished projects have made me into the person I am; it'd be nice to see a couple of them through at last.

However, if I was on £100k per annum, I'd quit full time employment - £1,000,000 could sustain my current lifestyle. Instead, I'd do some freelance work - journalism, maybe some scripts - whilst enjoying my life. I only get one shot.



</answer>

<answer from>



Maya R
Member since: 06 February 2008
Total points: 10799 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Current Events



</answer from>



<answer>



TV is one of the most insidious of the modern inventions. Quite apart from the promise it had at the beginning, as a means of entertainment and education, TV soon became the means of creating entire mindsets and controlling millions of minds.
Most do not question the integrity of the stuff they see, and sit motionless as each brainwashing session continues.
These mental lapses which they call programmes are nothing more than a mish mash of political propaganda and blatant commercial puff that seems to be what contemporary 'culture' parades itself as being. Its a concentration camp of the mind.
Our family gave up watching it two years ago along with unsubscribing from the daily newspaper. The changes were remarkable.Less stress 
and more time spent talking with friends and family as well as walks in the forest etc etc.
As Paul Simon said,"Switch off the TV and set yourself free"
He is right!



</answer>

</question from>



<question>



Those of you that correct our spelling mistakes...



(I'm guessing, whoever deleted this question a while ago, arranges they're m&m's before eating them).

Those of you that correct our spelling mistakes...
I have to ask, in the overall scheme of things, is it really that important?

I'm shocked (and highly amused) that you people seem to get so upset about something so insignificant.

Some of you go as far, and this is where my amusement turns to amazement, as to read a question starting "please help me I just don't now what to do" and you reply "actually it is spelt know".

This is such an anal response to an obviously serious question I half expect you to continue "...and the word know is derived from the greek...". I mean, for goodness sake, what is so lacking in your lives that you can't over look a grammer or spelling mistake and just answer the damn question. It's Yahoo!Answers, not Yahoo!eggheads. Come on people, lighten up.

Do you even consider that some people may be partially dislexic, foreign or young. Maybe they may feel embarrassed that you publicly pointed out their mistake.



And if someone says "actually, it's not Greek..." I swear I'll fall of my chair.



</question>



<answer from>

<answer>



OK, I don't correct people's spelling - although I AM paid to do so.
Let me ask you - isn't there something that makes you grit your teeth?  How about nails down a chalk board?  The sound of a bad player on a violin?  The site of a large person in tiny clothing they obviously bought when they WERE tiny?  How about a badly put together story in a book?  Or a delicious meal that has had the wrong type of sauce used in it?
Personally, badly spelled sentences and rubbish grammar do that to me.
I get toothache.  Please think twice before criticizing those of us with enough education to really dislike the ignorance that some people feel free to display.
Everyone makes errors - but that is why Yahoo and Microsoft gave us such reasonable spelling and grammar checkers.

And the ability to edit when we do make mistakes......



</answer>

<answer>



Yes they are anal people. It's like they just can't help themselves, they have a ridiculous sense of superiority over this poor person that just wants a bit of advice. You're very right in saying that not everybody has excellent spelling and grammar skills for many reasons, it doesn't necassarily mean they're thick. Sadly some people are just so far up their own backsides that they can't help it. Why on earth would someone delete a question like this? It's not offensive, racist or anything else that a lot of questions on here are yet most of them slip through the net with no complaint!

Just to mention to all those that say 'use the spell check', it is programmed to American spellings and is therefore useless to anyone from a different country (of which there are many on Y/A), in fact it's a complete pain.  It constantly flags up mistakes that don't exist if you don't live in the US!



</answer>

<question from>



Metalhea...
Member since: 06 April 2008
Total points: 2273 (Level 3)



</question from>



<question>



I like my best friend and really need advice....



About halfway through my ninth grade year, I started talking to this one girl(lets call her “Marie”. She was one of those people who didn’t seem to hang out with a lot of people(I wasn’t the most popular person in school, but I hung out with a fair amount of people). She had some friends, but they seemed more of casual friends than strong friends. Marie tended to wear darker clothes, like she might have some “prep” shirts, but they were always darker colors.



Anyways, we had been doing this one class project, and her group did some stuff with mine, and we started talking in school a bit, and also on myspace. As I talked to Marie, I realized how cool she seemed. She had a bit of a violent humor, could listen to(even make) perverted jokes without being disgusted, swore quite a bit, had a dominating air about her(She seemed pretty strong willed), and overall just seemed pretty damn cool. It was the end of the second quarter in school when I first started talking to her, and it wasn’t till almost the end of the year that we really started hanging out(we had a total of like two classes together and, thanks to assigned seating, we typically weren’t close to each other). This was also the time that I first began developing a crush on her. Finally, we got relatively close within one class setting, and we were able to talk and get to know each other better(my god, I hated that class, but it was much better with her in there).



Marie had been single up to this point in time. Quite literally, on the last day of school she started going out with this one kid(“Rob”) who had had a crush on her for awhile(he was my friend, but I really didn’t understand why they got together, they seemed too different – he was very hyper while she was much more reserved in her demeanor). Anyways, we continued to talk over myspace throughout the summer, but neither of us are big on talking on the phone, and distance wises, it was kind of hard for us to really hang out.



Once my sophomore year started, we began hanging out quite a lot more. Since I was already pretty good friends with Rob, us, two other kids, “Ron” and “BJ” who were like best friends with Rob and pretty good friends with me , and Marie would all hang out together. Ron and BJ were Marie’s best friends, with BJ being her very best friend. So, it was a pretty good group.



It was during this period that I became really good friends with Marie(I was essentially still a step below Ron and BJ though). We still didn’t hang out alot outside of school, but we talked over myspace all the time, and always hung out at school. We really began trusting each other during this period. I learned that she had a few self-harming tendencies(but this slowly went away within the next half a year or so), and this helped to change my view of certain types of people. Also, I found that if something I did bugged her, and she mentioned it, I was more than wiling to change(in other words, I quit “gay bashing”, saying certain vulgar words[none of the wondrous swear words though], and a few things like that). We began helping each other out more and more(for example, we had this one project in class that we were both working on individually, but mine essentially sucked, so, about three minutes before either of us had to go up and present, we agreed that if I did ninety percent of the talking, we go up as partners[we were allowed to but we had been working individually before] and use her nice-looking project). Somewhere during this period, her and Rob began having sex, too.



This was all good until BJ got a girlfriend(he was kind of one of those nerdy kids that are really into video games) and he started changing. I had never been great friends(more of casual friends with him, me and Ron were good friends though) with him, so I had no problem totally ditching him when Marie did. Ron, on the other hand, had a little bit more trouble with it, but he managed to stay friends with both of them. It was during the climax of this situation that I think I essentially took the place of BJ in relation to Marie(our friendship is different now than it was then, but at the time, that’s what it was like). That night, when her and BJ ceased to be friends(it had been building up for awhile, but there was one point when they had an argument and that was essentially it for them), I must have spent at least three hours straight just talking to her on myspace. This was when I learned her deepest secret(lets just say something went terribly wrong in her life). She felt that it was her fault, in some way, and so I told her repeatedly that it wasn’t. I don’t know if it got through to her, but I truly hope it did. It was at that point, when she opened herself up to me completely, that I realized and decided that I loved her(as a friend) and that I would always be there for her. (When I first told her that I would always be there for her, she was like “that’s a big promise to make” and I was like “I know, I plan to always be there for you if you need me”[and I’ve kept good on that promise thus far, and plan to continue to do so]) Since that night, we haven’t talked about her past and that tragedy, for we both know of it, and it’s like a mutual silent agreement not to mention it ever again(if she ever needs to talk or anything, I’m obviously gonna be there for her, but I won’t ever bring it up).



The semester ended, and our group was down to four, instead of five. Me and Rob grew distant, for I didn’t really ever see him(due to classes), but we were still friends and were able to talk when we were around each other. Marie and Rob seemed to have a love-hate relationship. She used to get angry with him frequently, and they quarreled quite a bit. She was still pretty good friends with Ron. 
However, Ron started really hanging out with this one group of kids who she didn’t like. I thought that most of the people were pretty decent, if they were by themselves, but they turned into assholes once they all got together. Marie just thought they were assholes. 
So, slowly, Ron grew distant from Marie, and our friendship lessened a bit(we’re still pretty good friend, though). Finally, him and Marie had a falling out, and they have been bitter towards each other ever since. This left me as Marie’s only best friend.



By this point in time, Marie was one of my best friends(the only person I had her underneath on my myspace was a kid I’ve known for a few years over a decade and hang out with all the time). We hung out all the time in school, and a little after school. We were so close that people mistook us as a couple fairly often(she had more classes with me than she did with Rob, so we were together more). And yes, I still had a crush on her at this time. But, of course, our friendship always came first(it’s not like there was much I could do, she had a boyfriend).



The year ended, and summer began. I was gone halfway across the world with this one summer program for three weeks, and she was the only person I kept in real contact with throughout the trip(I called her twice, and the first time we talked for over two hours, and the second time we talked for about half an hour(the delay between when you said something and the other person heard it just got to annoying). In other words, she got two and a half hours of talk time, my other friend altogether got between a quarter of an hour and a half an hour, and my family got twelve minutes of talking to me). Once I got back, she broke the news to me that she might be pregnant(her period was being uber gay). Her boyfriend, Rob, was out of town for the next week or two, and she didn’t want to go and buy a pregnancy test herself, so she asked me(in a very demur manner[it’s not something you get asked every day]) if I would go out and buy them for her. I was like “Marie, I said I would always be there for you, so yeah, I’ll get them for you”. As you can see, we were pretty damn good friends. (she wasn’t pregnant, by the way, her period was just being slow)

Junior year rolled around, and her and Rob’s relationship fell to pieces. She began hanging out with one of Rob’s best friends, “Jay”. Rob began getting pretty angry when she would go and hang out with Jay, and like drive around or go and get coffee or whatnot. This really strained their relationship. Then, one day, she kissed Jay. Her and Rob decided to try and fix their relationship at that point, once she revealed that to him, but this failed terribly. After getting drunk one night, her and Jay had sex, and that was the end of her and Rob. 
Despite her actions going against just about all my morals, I stuck by her side, as her best friend(I had told her I would, and I damn well meant it). Almost none of my friends wanted me to hang out with her anymore, but I really didn’t care. And, I still liked her.



There was about a month transition period in which she was single, but essentially going out with Jay. I almost think that Jay was a bounce back, or possibly a revenge thing. He was willing to say things to please her, do stuff for her(be “whipped”[just like how I do a lot of small things for her, so people always say I’m whipped by her]), and make promises to her. I dislike him(and Marie knows this, and she used to bug me about why I don’t like him, but she hasn’t asked me why for months now[essentially since they started arguing more]). Like, he reminds me of myself in some ways(he has a sense of humor, is willing to do small things for Marie, etc), but with a lack of morals, a sense of over-pride(it’s like he doesn’t believe he can be wrong[except with Marie, and only sometimes at that]), and more of a party side to him(according to Marie, I’m the “good kid” between me and her, whereas Jay goes out and drinks and does some drugs). 
Anyways, they seem to fight quite a lot actually. It’s almost a repeat of her last relationship, in my opinion(both Rob and Jay are emotional crybabies, in my opinion, they fight over dumb **** with Marie, and almost break up from time to time and then don’t[but Jay graduated this year, so maybe that’ll help sever their ties]).



Jay graduated this year, so that means that he got to take off the last week of school. Unfortunately, I got MRSA on my leg and so I only got to spend two days of that week at school, hanging out with Marie. When I was gone at the hospital though, I called her quite a bit(and like the phone keep dropping the call[I think that the medical equipment was killing it], so instead of just hanging up, we called each other back like half a thousand times). After school ended, her and Jay almost broke up, and she had me call her(I have wondrous dial up so I was on the internet and she told me to call her), and we talked for a good amount of time. Anyways, they worked it out, and are back together. But like we were at this parade thingy the other day and I ran into her and Jay didn’t seem all that enthusiastic, like she wanted to get rid of him. And that’s essentially where we’re at now.



Now, for between Marie’s and my relation….we hang out all the time at school, we actually talk on the phone from time to time, and hang out sometimes after school. She has become my very best friend, surpassing even my friend of over a decade, and I am still her very best friend(she doesn’t really have any other best friends, either). I help her out with the big things(the other day, she didn’t do a book report for this one class, so I sent her the report I had done earlier in the year so that she could just turn that one in[and she got a higher grade than what I got for my book report. Ironic, huh?]), and the small(picking up her pencil of she drops it, buying her something from a concert of her favorite band that she wasn’t able to make it to[with my own money]). She has always been there for me when I have needed her and she is the one person I know I can turn to to talk with if I really need to. She has ALWAYS helped me out when I needed it or asked. She is so amazing. For next year, we have coordinated our classes so that we can have the majority of them together(I think we got between two thirds and three fourths of them together next year). And, obviously, I still have that crush on her.



I want your opinions on this. Please.



</question>

<question>



Where can I buy a PERISCOPE?  ?



My partner is in the building trade and sometimes needs to be able to see into very small spaces (e.g. yesterday he cut a small hole in a ceiling, to try to ascertain which way the joists were running, but he couldn't see and kept having to cut more and more of it away till he ended up with quite a large hole!).
I have looked on Amazon and serached on Google but the only ones advertised are toy ones and they're not even currently available on Amazon!
Thanks :o)



</question>



<additional details>



FETU FAJIYAS, there is always one arrogant twat and this time it had to be you...there is a false ceiling under the real ceiling...and he has been working in the construction industry for years- he can fit bathrooms, kitchens, do plumb anything, do electrician work, paint, decorate, build walls and OH YES, he also has a certificate for being able to take down walls safely (not just anybody is allowed to do this, lest the building should collapse on their head.....so, why don't you just SHUT UP and keep your stupid, uninformed opinions to yourself??!!!  I'd be far happier trusting someone careful and cautious like he is, to check for a joist, than a silly fool who thins all there is to it is to "tap on the ceiling".....try knowing something about a subject before you proclaim yourself as the expert, ok?



</additional details>



<answer from>



Ithobel
Member since: 27 July 2008
Total points: 138 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



You can make one out of an orange juice carton and two compact mirrors -



At the top of one side of the carton, use a pencil to make three holes in a diagonal line.

Start at the top left corner of the box and head down towards the right.



Make three more holes in the same way at the bottom.



Flip the carton over, so that the side that was on the table is now facing up.

Make two more sets of holes like before, but this time starting in the top right corner of the box, and heading down to the left.



Take a look at the holes you made at the bottom of the carton. The holes in the corner of each side are either side of the face you now need to work on.

At the bottom of this side of the carton, make four holes in the shape of a rectangle.



On the opposite side to this one, make four more holes in the shape of a rectangle - this time at the top of the carton.



The holes you've made, are all to help you cut the box. Cut out the rectangle at the top of the box.



Do the same at the bottom of the carton.



Then cut down all the diagonal lines.



Finally slide the mirrors into the diagonal slots that you've just cut.



To make the periscope work as well as possible the two mirrors must be placed at exactly the same angle.



To do this, before you make the holes, cut a piece of card into a triangle shape and mark out where the holes will go.



Use the same piece of card to mark out where the holes will go at the top.



</answer>

<answer>



He can ascertain which way the joist run by simply tapping the ceiling with his finger and listening to the pitch.  When you hit a joist it will sound solid and not hollow.  I if I was a property owner I would be skeptical of someone that had to drill a hole to figure that out



</answer>

jamesdea...

<answer>



Oil is the reason. Are you kidding?  Oil is the reason the royal family of about 18,000 doesn't have to bring their country out of the dark ages and develop and compete in a modern world.  All they had to do was figure out how to make a hole in the ground and suck up the oil.  Forget putting the money into social services and thanks to good 'ol Islam, keep the women as second class citizen slaves.  Works for them.  And they love the conflict in the mid east.  If it weren't for that, the rest of the Arab nations would be all over Saudi Arabia.



</answer>



<answer from>



Elliot Ness
Member since: 04 July 2006
Total points: 9229 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



It all started with Petro dollars.  Although Dubai's (which is in the UAE, not Saudi as someone else has suggested) oil reserves are dwindling they still have a fair amount.  However, they have seen that the oil will not last forever so have heavily expanded into tourism, they are also the hub for most mid-east oil contractors and service companies.  As such they have a large ex-pat population.  They still practise conservitive laws and traditions, however they are somewhat relaxed.  The UAE is not Saudi, and women do have rights and have the choice of whether they wear traditional dress or not.  One thing about Dubai, it used to be a bit expensive and that helped keep the riff raff out, but recently there have been a spate of typical trailer trash crimes in UAE, sex on beaches, drunk and disorderly conduct, fighting on airplanes, etc.  Dubai has recently had a huge building boom, and everyone is making a profit, so they keep building.  One thing to remember as well is "it takes money to make money" They have LOTS of money, and "the more you have the more you make". So they still have petro-dollars coming in, but don't rely nearly as much on them as they used to.  They labour they have is also what the west would consider as cheap, but it is far from slavery, they pay better than the workers home industry, on average 3 times the wage.  So it is attractive for workers mainly from Asian countries to flock there to work as labourers.  Some employers have less than respectable working and living conditions for their workers but on average they are ok.  Dubai is a really nice place, and celebrates it's culture, history and heritage, and so long as you have a little self-disipline and act like a human and not an animal you will have a really good time.  A few other nice places to visit would be Abu Dhabi, Doha, and Bahrain.



</answer>



<answer from>



danielro...
Member since: 01 July 2008
Total points: 636 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Investment. There is no taxes and many people buy buildings etc. from the government of Dubai.



</answer>

<question>



If someone starts a fight with you, what should you do?



If someone starts a physical fight with you what do you think the best course of action is? Hit them back, run away, block their punches but don't hit back, or something else- what's your opinion?



</question>



<answer from>



Rock n' roll!
Member since: 11 July 2008
Total points: 1027 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>

Then I'd repeat my offer "I do not want to fight" and if they keep on going i'd knee them and then do a take-down position untill the teacher comes :)



</answer>



<asker's comment>

Tamara

<answer from>



jamal s
Member since: 19 July 2008
Total points: 1100 (Level 3)



Contributing In:



Other - Society & Culture



</answer from>



<answer>



It depends on what you're fighting for. You should always try to avoid physical violence if possible, especially if the fight is over something stupid. But as soon as the person makes a move, or they make it obvious that the situation can't be ended peacefully, you fight back. In a serious situation the person who makes the 1st hit is usually the one who wins.

You can't only block without hitting back, if you did, they'd only keep hitting until they got tired, or someone broke the fight up. You can't block or duck every punch or kick.

Peace



</answer>

I then said to my friend we were playing the prank on "what was that" et. then told her to stay there and I'll go check it out. Then I screamed and climbed out the window and shouted something like "please no, don't take me outside!" then I waited in the hedgerow with my friends outside. Five mins later my friend opened front door and looked around shouting our names. There was a fox making it's weird call which sounds really eerie and it was perfect. Anyway she walked into the lane, we crept out from the bushes from behind, and she screamed for ages! It was so funny. It worked so well, and she saw the funny side after. <answer>



England has become very culturally diverse - so to say 'English' can mean many ethnicities. 'English' people from hundreds of years ago may more than likely be descendants of Celts, Vikings, Romans or the French. Due to the Empire, and influx of foreigners in the 19th, 20th and 21st century, means there are now many English people whose descendants were born in the Middle East, the Caribbean, India or Pakistan.



</answer>



<answer from>



Jo-Ann M
Member since: 16 December 2007
Total points: 2372 (Level 3)



</answer from>

<question>



What are emo people all about?



what does emo mean



</question>



<answer from>



Cameron S
Member since: 02 July 2008
Total points: 236 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



emo-tional.



Source(s):



http://www.luv-emo.com/ &lt;--- tells you everything
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JGLv3IEL0... &lt;- shows you

But if you want to look hot why not try Visual Kei... It looks way better :P



</answer>



<answer from>



krash1980 ♂☿
Member since: 23 June 2008
Total points: 467 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Emo - short for Emotional Hardcore - a sub genre of Punk Rock music that emerged from the 80's Hardcore Punk scene in Washington DC in the early 80's.

There have been 3 Waves or Generations of Emo. The first two being part of the underground music scene. And the third which we know of today being the most commercialized form of Emo.

First Wave (1985-1994)

http://youtube.com/watch?v=Ob22sS5DiFY

Second Wave (1994-2000)

http://youtube.com/watch?v=QMkH6xi6-Og

Third Wave (2000-Present)

http://youtube.com/watch?v=jjWJfpODVIY

Misuse of the word Emo has become widespread in the US due to the popularity and distinctive attire worn by the Third Wave which was stolen from Heavy Metal, Punk Rock, and Gothic culture.

Just look at the answers posted below mine, many people have come to believe that Emo is a fashion, it isn't. The first two generations actually dressed quite differently.

Headbangers or Metalheads were the first to wear tight spandex denim and eye makeup in the early 80's. Androgynous fashion in rock music actually dates back to the early 1970's with the New York Dolls, who practically invented the Punk Rock.

EDIT: HELLBREEDER: so much for you being Goth, you obviously are lacking in a musical education.



</answer>



<answer from>



HELLBREE...
Member since: 18 September 2008
Total points: 86 (Level 1)



</answer from>

<answer from>



fahad khan
Member since: 09 April 2008
Total points: 140 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



emo is a genre of music that originated from hardcore punk, pop-punk and indie rock. It has since come to describe several variations of music with common roots and associated fashion and stereotypes.

The name "emo" has been in use in music circles since the 1990s, and as far back as the mid 1980s as "emotional hardcore" - describing a scene of punk bands in Washington, D.C. who made emotionally moving punk music about despair and heartache.

<answer from>



what measure is a nerd
Member since: 14 September 2008
Total points: 132 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Prejudice against gothic people is not racism. Racism only applies to prejudice relating to someone's ethnic background, like being black, white, Asian, Native American, etc. Regarding styles of dress, the word you would use to describe negative treatment or opinions is "prejudice," like "are you prejudice against people who follow emo fashion?"

As for gothic style, I would wear it if I had the money and the willpower to wear some of the uncomfortable fabrics and cuts of clothing that come with it. I only look down on goths if they choose elements of that style that are extremely passe (such as random black lipstick),  or extremely distasteful (such as oversexualized clothing in public or extremely disrespectful shirts). I look down on people wearing other fashions for the same things.



</answer>



<answer from>

Member since: 25 August 2008
Total points: 227 (Level 1)

<answer>



First, its not racism.  If you want any adults to take you seriously, you have to call it by a correct term, such as, are you prejudiced against gothic people? Or something of that nature.



You say you didnt call goth a race, but by using the term racist, you are in fact calling it a race.

I was goth in high school, and would be today if it werent for the real world.  My career is in child care, and unfortunatly, most parents are prejudiced against the gothic style.  In fact, the only real world careers that are ok with the gothic style is art related careers.  In any other career, you would either get know where, or constantly have to prove yourself to the people you work with that you are a serious adult.

What made me sooo mad about people who were/are against goths is that the say you are just following some current fad.  And dressing at the Gap and support Walmart and slave labor isnt following a fad?  Its a double standard, and I hate double standards.

I have found that the most common reason people are prejudiced though is because they simply dont understand it.  Its human nature to fear what we dont understand, and I am sure if you did some soul searching you could find something that you fear simply because you dont understand it.  Anyone who says they dont is a flat lier.

Every group has stereotypes, and the gothic stereotype is devil worship, being a kid, anarchy, opposition to authority, refusal to cooperate, partying, drugs, raves, ect.  In the work place, those are the LEAST desirable qualities.  As I already said, any goth in the adult work place would constantly be fighting to prove themselves against this stereotype.



</answer>

Member since: 08 June 2006

<answer>



Hehe I only found this out recently - Hump Day is Wednesday, so called because when you're working full-time Wednesday is the "hump" of the week - i.e. you get through Wednesday and you're over the hump and it's smooth sailing through til TGIF!

hump day is basicly a name for wednesday, or, the middle of the week.
it just refers to getting over the 3 day hump and making it through the hardest part of a new week.. the beginning!

basically it helps you look forward to the weekend.. theres no rituals or anything like that.. its just a name.. if you google it you probably can find some sites that have explanations if mine didnt make sense lol

wednesday is hump day. At the beginning of the week you fight up hill to get near the weekend. Thursday and Friday are downhill slides to the weekend. Thus Wednesday you get over the uphill hump to the downhill :o)

<answer>



It's Wednesday because it's in the middle of the typical work week.  So you are climbing up the hill on Mon. & Tues.,  and on top of the hill or on the "hump" on Wednesday.  Then on Thursday & Friday you slide right into the weekend.



You just keep working or doing whatever you are supposed to do.

<answer>



"Hump Day" is the day in the middle of the week, or Wednesday. Nothing really happens on Hump Day except for Ash Wednesday, or other holidays that may happen on different days like Christmas, Halloween, Valentine's, etc.

<question from>



Enrique
Member since: 10 September 2007
Total points: 390 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



What do you think about life?



I am not sure about my future in general, I am also not sure what I want to do either. I enjoy school, and I enjoy learning but I don't know what I could do for a job in the future. I plan to go to collage but I am not sure really for what though. I want to succeed in life.. but I want to enjoy life as well and not have to always be forced to do a job just so I can put food on my table. I know that sounds lazy, but if you think about it, does spending countless hours in an office for a paycheck really seem worth it. The only view you get is your computer screen and a lot of numbers. I want to see more than that, I want to live a life, go around and see the scenery on this damned earth.

I grew up with the fact that you have to work to get what you want in life, and I still find that true, especially in today's economy. Does anyone have any other details on how I can think about this. I am not asking you to answer my life long question, or just say "win the lottery, or become and Entrepreneur". I just want to be able to wake up in the future and not have to say "Time to go to work.. again".



Even if you have something small to say, it will at least make me ponder on it further.



</question>



<answer from>



day dreamer
Member since: 22 December 2007
Total points: 223 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



The thing is, everyone wishes that.  That's a fantasy that will never come true.  You can have your dream of "seeing the world" but you'll have to work for it too.  You can't have one or the other.  It'd be nice to wake up everyday and not have to worry about working, spending time at a job.  However, that's not reality and its not the way life works no matter how much you want it to.  The only thing you can do is choose a career you enjoy to make things a bit easier for you to get up in the morning and work.  I enjoy learning too and i love the outdoors.  I would hate to spend every second of my life doing the exact same thing...over and over and over and over... you get the picture... So I'm going to college to become a geologist.  I'll always be learning and I'll be able to work outdoors too.  To me that's not work, so if you find something you enjoy that won't be work either.  Its up to you.  Find something you enjoy and not consider it work or work in an office or whatever.  And there is always the choice of becoming a bum... I guess.. but ultimately won't you have to work to get food too when you beg for it on the streets.  In life you have to work.  There is no way around it, unless you're born rich, but most of us aren't that lucky.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



I understand completely what you are talking about, it's not that I have not come to that conclusion either I just like to keep thinking about it either way. Who knows I might find a proper conclusion that best fits me. If you have any more input, feel free to speak your mind, be skeptical.



</asker's comment>

<answer>

Never go shopping on an empty stomach - you WILL end up by unnecessary crap

<answer from>



jamal s
Member since: 19 July 2008
Total points: 1100 (Level 3)



Contributing In:



Other - Society & Culture



</answer from>



<answer>



It's easy to see how you got that outlook - it's because you were the object of the teasing. You cannot end every and all forms or instances of bullying, but you can influence the would-be bullies in your environment. Not just the ones that mess with you but the ones that mess with others as well.



Physical conditioning and learning self defense are good things that everyone should do/know. But they are not the solution to every single problem. Some problems can, and have to be, worked out peacefully, whether that means leaving them alone/avoiding them, talking with them, doing better than them in whatever "it" may be, or simply talking to them, there are alternatives.



There are some people who have to be put in their place from a good *** whoopin, those are usually the assholes who are set in their ways. But there are also those who only act out of ignorance or for whatever reason, and depending on the situation an *** whoopin may set them straight too. You may not want, or even care, to know why that person treated you the way they did, but there is a reason.



there are many different reasons why people bully others, and each reason depends on the person. There are only general similarities. There is something that that person lacks that they need to get by "taking it" directly or indirectly from others. Usually those who seem slow to defend themselves or lacking something themselves. A lot of times it's got something to do with respect. In any case, although some people would say ignore them, that may or may not solve the problem, depending on who it is you're dealing with and what your situation is. In any case, usually you should try to solve the problem, whether it be through peaceful or violent means. And of course, the physical means should always be the last option.

But in closing, the point is there is a cause for every action, and one specific action is not the end-all of any one problem. Education (whether that be direct or indirect, physical or non-physical) creates true equality, which gives way to justice and creates peace.

Peace



</answer>

Digipics D

</question from>



<question>



Are movies highly censored in America?



Having watched a lot of American movies we seem to get a lot of violence, swear words and sexual content shown in them.  Is that because we get the European version whereas you get a cleaned up version.  Or does the censorship change from state to state?



</question>



<additional details>



I can't remember but was the film Emmanuelle ever shown in American cinemas?



</additional details>



<answer from>



Earl s
Member since: 11 May 2006
Total points: 1413 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



The MPAA rates all movies before they are distributed in the USA.



R rated movies generally have violence & swearing, not as much sex. Some nudity but much sex. There was a movie made about how the ratings boards work. Too many religious people are on it.



NC-17 movies are unrated & can have anything. Unfortunately most movie theaters refuse to play such movies.



European movies we see , usually at art houses, have much more nudity and sex than American movies.



Source(s):



http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/This_Film_I...



</answer>



<asker's comment>



:-)



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Pastor G
Member since: 20 July 2008
Total points: 3233 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



No.

Movies are not censored at all in the USA.



</answer>



<answer from>



abradley...
Member since: 19 June 2008
Total points: 3210 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Censorship changes from state to state and country to country. Go outside the US and watch the news for a few weeks. You will soon realize that we have censorship here. We just don't call it censorship.



</answer>



<answer from>



Dart Swinger
Member since: 12 July 2007
Total points: 23107 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



States do have that authority.  It is the FCC (Federal Communications Commission) that regulates what can be broadcast over the public airwaves.  In movie theaters, we get the unedited version.

Many movies that are shown on broadcast TV are edited for content.  Cable and satellite broadcasts are more flexible.



</answer>
