<question from>



Horny guy
Member since: 14 September 2008
Total points: 95 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Why are men taller than women and why do men ave bigger bodies than women?



I ave always wondered why dat is! cud never grasp why men's bodies and height are diff 2 women, can sum1 answer dat for me?



</question>



<answer from>



Precious ツ
Member since: 10 September 2008
Total points: 372 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



That is not true. Both genders come in different sizes and shapes. I know many guys who are shorter than me and thinner than me :)



</answer>



<answer from>



Shaba
Member since: 15 March 2007
Total points: 7885 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



both men and women have the potential to grow to the same height.
however, different physiological processes in men and women determine how long and thickly built are their bodies.

men have testosterone, which increases muscle mass and decreases body fat (lucky bast*rds!)
women have estrogen, which increases body fat and doesnt do much for muscles.

about length:  the females' hormones cause the epiphyses (that thing found at the end of long bones, such as the bones of the legs and arms) to start growing faster than in males, thus females start getting taller before males do.  however, they close much earlier too, thus, while males continue growing, females stop much earlier, and thus become less tall than males.

hope this helped!



</answer>



<answer from>



SYJ
Member since: 28 August 2006
Total points: 6304 (Level 5)



</answer from>

<answer from>



Paul
Member since: 23 October 2007
Total points: 1134 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Ok for people saying that its not always the case, of course its not, but we're talking in general and these results will always prevail in a large-scale survey that the 'average' man is taller, stronger and heavier than the 'average' woman. Statistics aren't interested in the exceptions.

Men have more testosterone which is a booster in bone development and maturation so they have heavier and thicker bones.

Women have alot of estrogen which is naturally aromatized into testosterone and so because testosterone peaking is what stops the height increase in boys towards the end of puberty, happens sooner in women and so the average adult woman is shorter and stops growing sooner than boys.

Women also lose alot of calcium via bleeding during their period and also have to use alot of calcium and nutrient reserves for the maintenance of an egg inside their womb.

So a woman really is eating for two.



Having taken into consideration the biological factors which first perpetuated this trend, we can proceed to considering evolutionary dynamics which magnified these differences in favour of the survival of the human species.



Men being naturally larger and stronger as a result of their biology were better suited to the role of hunting, gathering food and protecting the family.



The stronger, larger, heavier men whom the women felt more protected with were likely to get the female and pass down their genes and the weaker males were either killed because they weren't built to survive or were not chosen by females to reproduce and so their inferior genes died out.



Men wanted women they could protect and so the more independent, stronger women were chosen against and the more petite, smaller, lighter and more vulnerable women were picked by men and naturally went for the larger male and so looking at the larger picture, that is why things are the way they are today if you're looking at it from a bioevolutionary point of view.

All the factors contribute to the typical female anatomy.



</answer>

<question from>



Rhianna

</question from>



<question>



What is 'twat'? I hear people saying it alot in the UK?



</question>



<additional details>



I have lived more here in the UK than the US but I feel stupid I don't know what these words mean



lol thanks Dr Nick, all I needed to know! I had a feeling. I've saved the urban dictionary to my favourites for future reference!



Cardiology Unit I do bank work on other wards though too

<answer>



twat = c u n t = p u s s y = vagina

Like the word "****," I've embraced the word "twat" as an empowering word for my bits.  At a gynecological appointment (in spite of my being a nurse), I'm just as likely to refer to my twat or **** as I am to refer to my vagina.  Not sure of  its relative use in the U.K. versus the U.S., but it seems to be commonly used in the two countries I've spent most of my life in:  Canada and the U.S.



Source(s):



It's worth noting that the single word in this answer that Yahoo! Answers has chosen to edit is the word C U N T.  I did not insert any asterisk euphemisms in my original answer.  Wonder if they edit the words '****' or '****.'



</answer>

<answer from>



midnight...
Member since: 25 June 2007
Total points: 42246 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Cancer



Other - Society & Culture



</answer from>



<answer>



Many people in our culture feel this way.  Our culture has put such a huge taboo on recognizing our sexuality that many people feel incomfortable.  I grew up thinking that penis and vagina were dirty words never to be said.  I was told I was going to hell when my mom found a vibrator in my room.  I asked to go to a gynocologist when I was 17 because I was having menstrual issues and she said no, that only married adults go to that kind of doctor.

Then I got cancer at 21.  I suddenly had to talk to everyone about my body and all its functions.  I had to be view while naked and poked and proded.  And I quickly got over it.

I have found that talking about these things in a clinical frame of mind (using the correct medical terms, ect) makes it easier to talk about.  Saying penis to me definatly makes a conversation about sex more comfortable than looking for every euphamism in the book because I am too weirded out to say penis.



As far as curse words....  Again, our culture makes them so taboo.  What I feel there is that..  what makes those specfic words bad?  Why is it ok to say 'shoot' but not the other word?  Why is it ok to say darn, but not the other word?  Gosh, but not god?  Freaking, but not f?  You know what I mean?  Does replacing the taboo word with a nontaboo word really make it different?  If I stump my toe and hollar DARN IT, is it really different than saying DA*N IT?  I mean, really, is it?  You are using it in the exact same context, so why is one ok and the other not?

At the end of the day, during cancer I had to make myself comfortable with talking about my body.  I find myself so liberated that I am no longer ashamed of my body.  I HATE that our culture teaches us that our bodies are dirty and shameful.  I dont think it does anything positive.  In fact, the largest negative that comes from it is parents being uncomfortable talking about it to their children.  During cancer, my mom was my care giver at home.  She got embaressed and upset that I had the nerve to say the word vagina in front of her, or that it didnt bother me to undress in front of doctors.  But the real problem is that she never discussed sex with me growing up.  No conversations at all except to say if you do it before marriage you go to hell.  Thats not healthy, and thats why our unplanned teen preg rates are so high.  In Canada, where the freely and openly give all children sex education, the unplanned teen preg rate is very very very low.



</answer>

Thanks
From Helena

<additional details>

<answer from>



Gemini
Member since: 18 January 2008
Total points: 4838 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



This is a good questtion.



I am retired but when I was working in a high pressured job that had many very exacting deadlines I would forgo lunch at times.  Grab a mars bar or something similar and not eat a meal of any description until I arrived home in the evening.



Only now, when  I stop, think, and remember do I realise how silly that was.



I guess there are very many people doing that now and I would tell them to think carefully about the risks they are taking with their own health.



</answer>



<asker's comment>

<answer>

<answer from>



scruffyc...
Member since: 13 June 2006
Total points: 25744 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



I usually buy my lunch at the store we are inventorying... the job requires a lot of physical labor, so when I eat lunch, I need it to have enough carbs to break down slowly, so that I do not become hungry before the day is over. We get only one break in a 10 - 12 hour work day, and that break is a 1-hour lunch.



Typically, I buy a sandwich, or something like that, at the deli... or I buy a fish sandwich at the McDonalds' that are usually inside the store we are inventorying. For a drink, I almost always get a bottle of water... and sometimes I supplement that with either orange juice (Simply Orange) or lemonade (Simply Lemonade). Also... I like dessert, so I usually get a York Peppermint Patty for dessert.



</answer>

<question from>

</question from>



<question>



Do you have any 'limiting beliefs' that are holding you back from something?

<question from>



Gianni M.
Member since: 26 October 2008
Total points: 46 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



How can I improve my Speech/ The way I talk???? Please help.?



I've been noticing the reason why some people don't take me seriously whatsoever, its because of the way I talk! First and foremost, I am Tall, very Attractive, Smart, Intelligent, Positive person, I have a unique personality. BUT For as long as I can remember people never take me seriously and some people actually think i'm slow, dumb, incompetent or mentally crazy!!!!!! This really has gotten to my head and honestly my self esteem has gone down, I find myself questioning my own intelligence and my own self worth. I think people around me look at me this way because when I talk i sound "slow" and sound almost childish and naive, as if I'm new in this world. I think when I talk I sound childish and extremely naive, WHEN I'M NOT. When i speak I sometimes don't speak clearly, sometimes stutter (not badly). This is something I myself have recently noticed, no one has told me this. This is something that came to my awareness a couple months ago. I have noticed that when I do talk as clearly as i possibly can and speak with a loud crisp tone people treat me differently, as if they look at me in a different manner. Is there any way I can improve and strengthen my speech??? Speak with authority and confidence and not sound slow or mentally incompetent. (by the way do any of you think I'm mentally incompetent by reading this??, answer honestly) Thanks.



</question>



<additional details>



No I'm not a dumb or unintelligent person. I'm smarter than the average.



</additional details>



<answer from>



dougness...
Member since: 16 February 2007
Total points: 2497 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Practice in front of a mirror is your best option.



Its easy to judge people as dumb when they have a dumb sounding voice. For guys it usually low and ape sounding. For girls its usually a high girly voice with the same inflection at the end.



Try not talking. Talk as little as possible.  When you do be confident and forceful with your words. Sometimes silence is the best tool of influence



Listen to how people respond to your ideas. There is of course a possibility that your just not that smart



</answer>



<answer from>



Musica
Member since: 05 July 2006
Total points: 24594 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Other - Society & Culture



</answer from>



<answer>



Sign up for Toastmasters or a formal speech class at a college.



Source(s):



http://www.toastmasters.org/



</answer>

<question>



Country least subject to censorship and social taboos?



I'm not talking about political censorship here, as many countries are free as far as political expression goes, I'm taling about censorship as far as the media goes. For example, in the US I feel the subject of sex is considered taboo in the media and is always spoken about in a "hush-hush" manner, and reference to drugs is kept to an absolute minimun, colourful language is also highly controversial.



Which country would you say is lease sensitive to "taboo" subjects, and prehaps has the least social taboos, and has media which is least subject to censorship as far as violence, sex, drugs, swearing, goes.



I hope I've articulated what I'm trying to say well enough.



Thanks



</question>

Amelia Y

<answer>



I find that very often it's in the title that you give your question - If you give a title that is too long no-one will bother reading etc . You have to make sure the title makes people want to open your question and it has to be a title that people think that they can genuinely help you with so don't be too specific.



Also , make sure that your question itself itn't too long because otherwise people cant be bothered to read it - i know i never can ! So really summarise your questions .



Other than that, make sure they are in the right category of questioning etc



good luck xx



</answer>

<question>



Why Do Women Feel Offended By Seeing Another Woman's Head Covered?



</question>



<answer from>



mufasa10...
Member since: 22 May 2007
Total points: 2932 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



I would assume because it is a sign of male domination and oppression...



</answer>



<answer from>



Jegged
Member since: 28 October 2008
Total points: 125 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I'm assuming the head covering you're referring to is the hijab, worn by Muslim women in public.



The reason it is seen as offensive to women is that it represents a form of oppression, as most women were forced to wear them by their families (this is still often the case). Many women choose to wear them willingly in western cultures, but this does not erase the fact that they are a symbol of a male domination over women in Islamic cultures.



</answer>



<answer from>



teresath...
Member since: 04 April 2006
Total points: 52685 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



Because some women assume that the woman keeps her head covered out of modesty... and that implies that a woman who DOESN'T cover her head is immodest or impure.



Concealing the body implies that there is something wrong or shameful about the body, that it should be hidden... and many liberated women don't like to be told that there is something wrong about their natural bodies.  Many women want to feel that their bodies are just fine the way they are, and that they shouldn't have to cover up to be treated with respect or to be seen as a good person.



Ultimately, however, every woman should respect the choice of every other woman, no matter what it is.  It's unfair to assume that the other person is simply mindlessly following sexist cultural dictates of modesty or sexiness; it's better to give the other person the benefit of the doubt and assume they made the choice that was right for them, and it's not meant to be a reflection or judgement on anyone else.



</answer>



<answer from>



cristina...
Member since: 11 October 2008
Total points: 2603 (Level 4)



Contributing In:

</answer from>



<answer>



I'm not offended as long as it is her free will and not something forced on her under threat of severe punishment.



</answer>

<answer>

kheserth...
Member since: 02 August 2006
Total points: 17280 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Circumcision was introduced into mainstream american society in an attempt to limit masturbation by teenage boys.  Whether or not it had any impact back then, it seems to have little impact now.



It was only when circumcicion had been in full swing for a generation, and fear of masturbation had dropped out of the medical literature, that 'hygiene' became the reason.  Its easy to say that it is 'cleaner' - our fingers would similarly be 'cleaner' if we removed the fingernails.  But the benefit is minimal, cleaning is easy, and it only seems reasonable because circumcision had _allready_ become normal.  Other countries that did not share the puritan fear of masturbation never started circumcising in large numbers, and certainly didn't pick it up for hygiene reasons.



</answer>

<answer>



Circumcision in America thrives based on a mixture of culture, ignornance and the insecurity of circumcised men.



As you astutely point out, the "medical" benefits of circumcision are hogwash. If they were, the more than 80 percent of men in the world who have their penises INTACT would be sick as dogs. But they're not, because circumcision doesn't cure or prevent a damn thing.



Circumcision was put into place as a culture in the US shortly after World War II and the country has yet to shake it off. While it's not ABNORMAL to not be circumcised, the majority of males still are. The stats nationwide break down to 60 percent circumcised, 40 not.



And when circumcised men become fathers, they insist rabidly that their sons MUST be circumcised like them. Son must match father. If it sounds creepy, it's cause it is. Who the hell goes around playing a penis matching game with their father?



Anyway, to answer your question again: Yes, circumcision in America is purely cultural.



</answer>

<answer>



Circumcision is done in the USA for cultural, religious, and medical reasons.  The reason it has been sustained for so long is because there are medical benefits to this.



The UK was at one time 40 percent circumcised.  the only reason it dropped is because the NHS wont pay for it.



The upper class in the UK still circumcise culturally just as they do in the us.  Prince Charles and his two sons are all circumcised.



If you have not heard of any medical conditions from being uncircumcised, then you have been looking in the wrong place.



Just do a search here on yahoo answers for phimosis, balanitis or foreskin problems or uncircumcised.



here is an article and you can look at all the foreskin questions while you are there:



http://www.netdoctor.co.uk/ate/menshealt...
http://www.netdoctor.co.uk/ate/menshealt...
http://www.netdoctor.co.uk/ate/menshealt...



It is also done routinely in Canada, The Philippines, Korea and it is growing in practice.  The Chinese are also considering adopting the procedure due to the increasing incidence of HIV and other STDS.



Source(s):



http://www.aboutcirc.com/
http://www.medicirc.org/
http://www.circumcisioninfo.com/index_ho...
http://www.circinfo.net/

<answer>



What's the rush? You're ONLY 17! Why not enjoy being a teenager now instead of being in such a hurry to grow up so fast and then get tied down and possibly feel trapped.



The problem comes in because so many young people THINK they're ready when in reality they are not!



Statistics show that people who marry in their teens or marry for reasons of pregnancy have a higher likelihood of divorce. These were ALL people who allegedly "considered the factors" and then had second thoughts after the fact. Then it's the taxpayer who winds up shouldering the burden.



No having a baby outside of marriage isn't the end of the world...but it's not the best circumstance...either for the parent or the child. It's like walking uphill against the wind.



If you're truly serious, then you should wait until you are older (at least over 21), ideally married, and have established careers (so you and your child don't wind up on welfare when the father abandons you as so many often do).  You have the rest of your life to become a parent. So sloooow down.



</answer>

<answer>



I think you know the answer to that. If you need the money, you need to keep your job until you can find another. That's a no brainer.



What you might what to do is start looking at your job in a positive rather than a negative way. Not easy I know, but it just might make your time on the job a little easier for you.



You do have a lot to be thankful for, You have a job. You are paying your bills, you have a roof over your head, and you have money to buy food, so you aren't starving.



There are a lot of people in this world who would love to trade places with you.



Having said that, I truly hope that you are able to find a job that you really enjoy going to because it is hard to have to go to work every day doing something that you don't like.



Good Luck to you!



</answer>

<question from>



Out of Q's
Member since: 23 April 2008

</question from>



<question>



What do you think of the idea of saving your first kiss for your future husband?



I know a lot of people wear "promise rings" to show chastity, but should chastity include kissing as well?



What do you think? I've seen some people who think kissing--and more-- before marriage is all right, while some make an arguement that just kissing before marriage is fine, and some think total chastity is best.



</question>



<answer from>



duaernil
Member since: 12 April 2007
Total points: 4003 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Ok the romantic thought is there but realistically...



What if you wait until that day comes and he finds out you are a horrible kisser? I'm not saying that you are a horrible kisser but some people need practice. Most times its the guy that needs help. Some guys are slobberers (wet kisses) so it takes a girl who can deal with the slobber by sucking as they kiss, basically drinking it. I guess that brings new meaning to the term "drinking in the kiss".



Do you know your future husband? If not they I don't see why you should wait. I'm not saying go and sleep with everybody. But its really weird to have a kiss with someone who doesn't know how.



Edit:
This is the definition of chastity:
1: the quality or state of being chaste: as a: abstention from unlawful sexual intercourse b: abstention from all sexual intercourse c: purity in conduct and intention d: restraint and simplicity in design or expression



2: personal integrity



It doesn't say you can't kiss so I would say it is okay. But what it boils down to is what is going to keep you chaste? If you are kissing while laying in bed that is likely to lead to something more. Its your call really. And if this future husband of yours respects you he will respect your wishes and wait.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thanks. The first answer with a real definition.



</asker's comment>

<question>



What do American call pants?

<answer from>



Mortifer...
Member since: 31 July 2006

<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Usually we call them "underwear" or "panties". "Underwear" is more common, though. It also depends on what kind you're talking about...



Source(s):



I'm American. ^_^



</answer>



<asker's comment>

</asker's comment>

<question from>



Poyzin
Member since: 21 October 2008
Total points: 114 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Why do so many people think that Humans are mean and cruel, especially towards animals? If your cat was sudden?



If your cute little cat named Fluffy were suddenly 4 feet tall at the shoulder and 300 pounds, you would not survive another night. He would be latched onto your jugular vein and you'd be dinner.
Almost all large animals, whether herbivores or carnivores are known to kill humans. .Hippos and Elephants eat plants, but they kill more people than crocodiles or sharks.
Of course, crocs and sharks kill a lot of people too.
Not to mention wolves, bears, and tigers etc.
My point is, your pets would kill you instantly if they were large enough, and you'd be doggy doo within 12 hours.
Chew on that :)



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



Well, that's not exactly true. There are domesticated large cats and there were actually two people that "owned" a lion that they had to release into the wilderness. They went to go find him a few years later and not only did he remember them but he also introduced them to his "wife". But anyway, either way, that doesn't justify being cruel to animals. We do kill animals for food, just like they would kill us but it would be hard to find some animal that gets together all of their friends and goes hunting for other animals for sport. I understand what you're saying but it's just not the same thing. Being cruel and surviving are too different things. And also, we're humans. We don't "need" to kill other animals at all. If they do, they die. If we don't we may be malnourished but we certainly wouldn't die of starvation.



</answer>

Ideally I would love to move out and become completely independent but I'm not sure as to the right way of going about it. For the last 4 years I have been working at various restaurants, the last one being a fifteen minute drive away, which wasn't too good for gas, and I don't have any budget plan, I just buy things, small things, coffee, and about a book a week, I owe 350 dollars to my bank and when I bought a piano on credit, which I will never use again, it has taken me a year and a half to pay it off, I have probably given them close to 2000 dollars total trying to pay it back. At this point I feel trapped and doomed to a life of poverty. I know I am in a better situation than a lot of people, but this is how I feel. Working at these dead end jobs because I can't afford to pay for college, and when I go I can't stand it because it's all a LIE...it teaches you nothing about yourself, it prepares you to be the slaves of lazy older slaves who have inherited the top positions of these companies that don't require any real effort to work for, so we get our little slips of paper that declare that we have been robbed of a **** load of money because we are the blood that the colleges suck from our veins. Unfortunately these are the thoughts that go through my mind about these issues. I firmly believe that everyone has become a zombie to the outside world and they think that it is normal to sit in a room and learn things that they have no interest in, working long and hard hours on it so that we can spend more money on it and waste more time on it for a certain amount of time so as to ensure that there is always a steady income flowing from that part of the big ugly economy, enslaving everyone for the "greater good" of money. What I am trying to ask is that is it possible for a person in today's society to not go to college and still succeed, or are mostly all doors to all businesses closed to those who don't slave away on trying to know a bunch of various facts from different subjects that they could easily find better information for using other means, for a lot less money, and more efficiently because of instead of taking all types of courses involved in different subjects and only remembering bits and pieces of each, one can channel one's effort and energy toward the subjects one wants to learn about and become as best as possible in that area?



</question>

Try to be less critical of my opinions and more focused on what you think.



I can't sell my piano and throw my dreams away for some money in the short term.



</additional details>

<question from>



jnayoub1...
Member since: 14 January 2008

</question from>



<question>



I need some help gathering facts?



I am presenting an argument around alcohol. I need facts like those listed bellow, as well as their sources. I have been gathering my own, but I would like to overwhelm them with the facts. So, thank you in advance.



Example Facts-
Alcohol is referred to as a "social lubricant"
7 of 10 Americans drink alcohol
1 of those 7 are alcoholics
for those of you incapable of simple math, 10% of Americans 21 or older (but lets be honest you and I both know, very few people wait till they are 21)
40% of adult Americans have direct family experience with alcohol abuse.



54% of murders and attempted murders
68% of manslaughters
52% of rape/sexual assaults
48% of robberies
are alcohol related



There are 3 alcohol related fatalities per day in Florida alone
1.4 million people were arrested for DUI/DWI in the US, but that didn't stop the 15,786 deaths in drunk driving cases.... Think it's going down?



drunk driving crashes in Florida
1997 457
1998 510
1999 518
2000 515
2001 555



It has been proven that drinking alcohol greatly increases your chances of getting cancer of the mouth, pharynx, larynx and esophagus



~ 1/1000 babies are born with Fetal Alcohol Syndrome today



90% of students drink alcohol
55% are binge drinkers
35% are frequent binge drinkers
&gt;20% are alcoholics of have some other diagnosable drinking disorder



for those of you who liked to complain about government finances....
Leon County had to spend ~$61 million in 2000 fighting underage drinking
there are 3077 Counties in the US, but for the benefit of the doubt lets take that figure and drop it down to $10 million county^-1



Want to know what the first stages of alcoholism are? Dependence on the mood altering ability of alcohol. Ie drinking to perk up, calm down, celebrate, mourn or to be sociable.



1400 college students age 18-24 die every year due to alcohol abuse. The average college student spends $900 dollars a semester on alcohol.



20% of corn produced goes to alcohol production. However the government subsidizes those farms $15 billion in total because more fossil energy is used to produce alcohol from corn, than alcohols calorific value.



</question>

Anybody in a vehicle will benefit from  it, by being protected from ejection or blunt trauma to their body.



This law, which is broken and fined for many times, has saved countless lives from window ejection.

<question>

OK, I am 16 and work at McDonald's. I was promoted in August from Crew Trainer to Team Leader. It is quite a big change, more responsibility, etc. But immediately after my promotion, one of my former Crew Trainers was really jealous, everyone could tell. She even came up to me a day later and said "I would make a great Team Leader too, I work twice as many hours as you too".



Lately she has taken way too far, she has freaked out at two managers telling them she deserves to be promoted, and she deserves it. She even back stabs me to the managers and tells them things I say (she tries to be my friend, and being young and trying to be nice, go with it, and I talk to her), she exaggerates what I say to make it sound like I'm really bad and she exaggerates what I say.



It is EXTREMELY un-professional and I can't being working everyday when its a soap opera. I think I should just go to the manager and tell her how I feel, and tell her that she should demote me, and give it to her since she wants it way more then me, and I'll tell her its not worth the 45 cent raise to put up with all this stress.



What do you think I should do?



</question>



<additional details>



The manger might not except it. But at least then they will know that I am damn well fed-up with this. If all else fails I can quit and take my awesome experience elsewhere, its not worth my youth to put up with this, I got my whole life ahead.



The giving her what she wants part. She feels like she deserves it, but if she gets promoted on the grounds that I stepped down, she would feel like she has not earned it.



</additional details>



<answer from>



Bobby B
Member since: 22 October 2008
Total points: 151 (Level 1)



</answer from>

I don't see why you should be demoted because someone else is jealous and won't stfu.  If you talk to the manager, you should tell them you are fed up with listening to this person, and ask what should be done about it.



</answer>



<answer from>



Jules
Member since: 05 September 2007

<answer>

Be strong! Try talking to your manager (if he is approachable) and tell him what's going on.

bellybut...
Member since: 10 April 2006

</question from>



<question>



Are you French men attracted black american women? French men only please.?



I was just wondering if French men were attracted to black american women. I am a black woman from america and I will be moving from to France (I also speak French). What areas of France should I move to to find a man to love me? Answer this question only if you are a French man living in France. Thank you for taking the time out to answer this.



</question>



<answer from>



Musica
Member since: 05 July 2006
Total points: 23805 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Other - Society & Culture



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Now, you didn't REALLY think those of us who are neither French living in France nor White nor male would ignore this question, did you?  lol



Here's my 2 cent from a black woman who has dated European men.



Relax. Your chances for finding romance in France are as good as anyone else's. Some white frenchmen like Black women. Some don't. Same as anyplace else.



Heck, there's even one European prince who married a Black woman.  She's the Princess Angela of Leichenstein.  Lest we forget, Prince Albert of Monaco fathered a half-Black child with a woman he'd been involved with for several years.



I know personally of a number of Black American women who are dating or married to men from all over Europe.



Just be yourself...and don't limit yourself...and the right guy will come along.



Your biggest worry really should be if the guy who is hitting you up really is single and available...or even straight for that matter!  Married men in France are notorious for cheating with single American women and breaking their hearts...so be careful.



as for the last bit, I learned that lesson the hard way....when I was 30, I went out on one date with a Frenchman who was attending my church. Turned out he was a closeted gay and involved with the church organist  :(



Source(s):



http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Princess_An...



</answer>

<question from>



Kayla
Member since: 02 January 2008
Total points: 70 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



State IDs- what are they?



What's a state ID and what can you do with it? Can you buy cigarettes with it?



Also, does it look like a drivers license? Does it have your picture on it?



And what exactly is its purpose? Is it for people who can't drive but are 18 & older?



</question>



<answer from>



WithLove Joe James
Member since: 06 November 2006
Total points: 1291 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



It is a valid ID issued by State Governments, It saves the same function as DL. You can use it where official ID is required (assuming you have no DL). It has your picture, may or maynot look like DL, but serves the same function as DL EXCEPT it is not for Driving.



</answer>



<answer from>



Michael L
Member since: 24 May 2007
Total points: 143 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



it is for everything but driving
it has all the same stuff it just says *not a valid drivers lisences*



</answer>

<question from>

</question from>



<question>



What are your feelings on?



Euthanasia?



</question>



<additional details>



I should have made myself clear...I mean Human...I have an Elderly Neighbor that has ALS (Lou Gherrigs Disease) he is seeing a Physician in Oregon about possibly doing this. I know the Prognosis of this disease and I understand where he is seeing this as his ONLY way out...but at the same time it is breaking my heart...He's Such a wonderful man and neighbor.



I give NO thumbs down...



</additional details>



<answer from>



Aaron's Mommy
Member since: 01 February 2007
Total points: 4950 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



What a tough one.  My grandmother is 93 and in relatively good health.  I visited her a month ago, at the manor where she has lived for 4 years.  She talked often about hoping she doesn't live too much longer.  She is a strong woman and has a very sharp mind which is fading.  She gets frustrated daily because her short term memory is not what it used to be.  She is very fearful that one day she will be sitting alone in the corner, not having a clue about what is going on in the world.  I think it should be her right to end her life if she wanted to.  But, sometimes people feel one way, but with proper care, may feel differently.



If some one could determine a person was of sound mind, I think it is your choice.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



T/Y Everyone for your answers...but it really came down to having to choose between you and Steph...both answers were what I was looking for to deal with this heart-wrenching Delimma!You both made it a little clearer.~~Much Aloha to You Both~~



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



royalbir...
Member since: 29 May 2008
Total points: 2938 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



I don't think it's appropriate to take human life, no matter the suffering.  I visited my grandmother when she was very ill and dying.  She had two broken femurs and a ruptured intestine and all sorts of other ailments and was in constant pain and delirious, but I still think it's morally wrong to kill just to ease her pain.  It's pretty much the same thing as suicide.



Source(s):



LDS



</answer>



<answer from>



Steph
Member since: 06 September 2007
Total points: 4900 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Other - Society & Culture



</answer from>



<answer>



I used to think it was a horrible thing that people would do because they were lazy and didn't want to take care of the sick or elderly.  I had to change my opinion as I watched my grandmother die a horrible death from pancreatic cancer.  It was the most awful thing I have ever had to witness.



She was my rock for my entire life.  She was the only person that I ever KNEW loved me and I love her so much.  She dwindled to nothing and was unconscious, most of the time, without the ability to wake up.  The only thing she could do was to moan in agony.  She couldn't eat and she had orders in place to not take a feeding tube.  She was in horrible pain, even an animal shouldn't be forced to suffer the way she had to.  She was a Christian and knew she was going to Heaven.  I would have given anything if someone could have given her a lethal dose of morphine and let go to sleep peacefully.  It still breaks my heart to think about it.  I would love to have her back, in good health,  for 5 minutes because I miss her so much.  Letting go of her was the hardest thing I have ever had to do.



</answer>

<question>



How can one person helps to save the World?



Today we all face a great challenge. The use of fossil fuels to create electricity and power cars, trucks and planes has begun to impact the global climate. Without immediate action, many scientists predict climate change may soon cause major crop losses and lack of drinking water throughout the world.



Our lives and the lives of our children and grandchildren now depend upon each of us taking immediate action to stop climate change. This may seem like an overwhelming task, but it isn't. Stopping climate change is a simple problem that each of us has the ability to solve.



Many people look to governments, businesses and nonprofit organizations to solve our environmental problems. In reality, however, no organization or government can stop climate change, only individuals can. Each of us has the ability to make minor changes to our own lives that can have a rapid and positive impact on the global environment.



</question>

<question from>

<question>



What would you do if the world STOOD STILL?

<answer>

<question>



Why is Australia so strong for a Nation of only 21,000,000 people?

</question>



<answer from>



Commande...
Member since: 23 March 2008
Total points: 835 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Australia has a national identity for being 'sporty' and giving everyone a 'fair go' - or at least it likes to think itself as being those things. Australia spends a lot of money promoting sport so that the people living there can be healthier and they can become better known as a country.



</answer>

Eoredd
Member since: 20 November 2006
Total points: 28511 (Level 7)



</answer from>

<original file>12355.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk85923.txt</current file name>




<category>



Society & Culture



Other - Society & Culture



</category>



<question from>



sebbie
Member since: 19 October 2007
Total points: 91 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



What is the 'American Dream'?



Need to include it in an essay so it needs to be formal, not just 'its where u live happy' or something! :)



</question>



<answer from>



i neva 4get
Member since: 22 June 2008
Total points: 1694 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



i have an american dream



some time in the future im going to go on holiday to america im going to tour it



im going to visit every part and try so much new stuff



so thats my version of the american dream



</answer>



<answer from>



PJ
Member since: 22 May 2007
Total points: 764 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



The American Dream is belief in the freedom that allows all citizens and residents of the United States to pursue their goals in life through hard work. Today, it often refers to one's material prosperity, which is dependent upon one's abilities and work ethic, and not on a rigid class structure.



Although the phrase's meaning has evolved over the course of American history, for some people, it is the opportunity to achieve greater material prosperity than was possible in their countries of origin. For others it is the opportunity for their children to grow up and receive an education and its consequent career opportunities. It is the opportunity to make individual choices without the restrictions of class, caste, religion, race, or ethnic group.



Source(s):



http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Dr...



</answer>

</answer>

<answer>



I have, you obviously need to make sure you have some savings or another source of income otherwise I would strongly advise against it.
It's getting harder and harder to get a job in this country so make sure you aren't shooting yourself in the foot just 'cos you are feeling a bit down, don't let the fact that your ex is in every thought cloud your judgement.



Good luck.



</answer>

<question>



Girls, do you ever go anywhere barefoot?



if so where? how long for? do u take shoes? and how dirty do your feet get?



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



I don't tend to go out barefoot but if the shoes are crippling it has been known for me to take them off once I am at somewhere..thats the problem with so many lovely looking shoes, they murder your feet!



It kinda depends where you are going how dirty your feet get..surprisingly I have got less dirty feet from some pavements than certain pubs/clubs!!



I would definitely suggest you take a pair of shoes with you, as some pubs or whatever can be really gross, and you wouldn't want to be walking through some of those places without any shoes on!  And be prepared for a lot of foot scrubbing when you get home!



</answer>

<question>



How has the Credit Crunch and Recession effected people giving to charity?



Are people becoming less charitable? Have you seen any examples?



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



The Credit Crunch and Recession have effected people giving to charity as people are struggling with their mortgages and are facing repossessions so they are saving up money and not giving like some people do regularly.



Most people are really tight with money but they still try give to charity as much as they can, but because of the credit crunch their wages are affected as they work on commission.



Hope it Helps X

<question from>



watashik...
Member since: 25 August 2008
Total points: 497 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



What was the culture like in Pakistan before the whole Talibization and extremism?



I want Pakistanis (or anyone) who know what I'm ACTUALLY talking about to answer this question.



I was born to Turkish parents. My dad was in the embassy in Islamabad, Pakistan for 5 years. I lived in Pakistan from 1988 to 1993. I then came to the US in 1993, and became a citizen of this country.



Anyways, I had a unique experience in Pakistan. The culture was up and booming in Pakistan. I studied in an international school in Islamabad, and the media was definite pro-America. The Pakistani kids with me were REALLY into the rock culture of the west, and I developed my "fatal" addiction to Led Zeppelin and The Beatles in Pakistan. I formed a rock band with some kids there, had posters plastered all over my room; and had all the rock albums. Those were great days for me.



Pakistan had a unique culture at my time there: Benazir Bhutto was the prime minister, and there was a really 'hip' element in Pakistan then. Female music artists like Nazia Hasan were prevalent too. At my time in Pakistan, i saw true rockers there, and had an amazing time. They showed all the cool stuff on TV, all the cool ads (like Don Carlos). And the girls were just so cool at that time.



I will cherish my five years in Pakistan, and will reminisce those times; because i had cool amazing friends. However, it saddens me what the country is going through today. I would love to visit that country sometime if they still had those people there.



So, moderate Pakistanis, please give me your analysis on what you think the Pakistani culture was like in the past. And leave behind some good memories.



This is not a question to offend anyone, so please answer if you know SOMETHING about it.



</question>



<answer from>



ahern.lu...
Member since: 20 June 2008
Total points: 18 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



i think its something to do with tribal warfare.



</answer>

</asker's comment>

<original file>14447.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk88247.txt</current file name>




<category>



Society & Culture



Other - Society & Culture



</category>



<question from>



Hush
Member since: 09 October 2008
Total points: 131 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



For people around or born in the 1970's In the United Kingdom?



Please can you tell me what life was like . It's for a school project. I know a little bit but personal experiences will help . Women can you please tell me what it was like getting the equal pay act, did people get made redundant or was that the 80's ?  Please help and thank you for all your answers .



</question>



<answer from>



paul
Member since: 31 October 2008
Total points: 143 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Summers were hotter, the mud used to crack.  You could play out without fear, even after dark.  Street parties happened a lot.  You could play conkers in school.  We weren't wrapped up in cotton wool.



We had respect and a healthy fear of older people.  If you gave cheek and they stopped to confront you, you ran away with genuine fear.



I'd say it was very much like growing up in any other country and things have degenerated the world over.



</answer>



<answer from>



Bonkers !!!!!
Member since: 27 October 2008
Total points: 151 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



i was born in 1981...



</answer>



<answer from>



THE MIGHTY RA
Member since: 26 March 2008
Total points: 21737 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Iwas born in 1973 in Plymouth, I remember being allowed to go to school when I was 4 years old I was brought up in Devonport whis is  a rough area of the city but back then everyone was poor, they were all in the same boat, when I was 5 I moved to Tavistock a town on the edge of the moors about 15 miles away, I remember before we left Plymouth we celebrated the queens Silver Jubilee and I dressed up as Mrs Mop, (I kept on getting told off for eating the candy cigarettes)  Life was rural in Tavistock at the time, but the people seemed richer, my dad didnt have  a TV for some years yet.  It was still the middle of the cold war and I remember being upset because I saw a map on the news and it showed the SW of England as a major target for a Soviet tactical nuclear missile strike.  When I left school 1989 it was the middle of  a recession the year before my friends had all got jobs in construction and were earning amounts that you would expect school leavers to earn even now, the recession put an end to that, soon, there were well over 3 million people on the dole, including me and all of my school leaver friends, I went on a YTS scheme and earned £29.50 a week, when I qualified in Horticulture, they threw me off the scheme so they didn't have to pay any money and take me on.  I remember that if you were naughty at primary school you would get a smacked bottom in front of the whole class.  Thats just  a few memories, but here are some links that might help you out.
1977
The silver jubilee (including a photo of  a street party in Plymouth of all places)
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Silver_Jubi...



1985
The live aid concert, this was BIG at the time
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Live_Aid



1985 Police oppresssion, the battle of the beanfield
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_t...



1990
The poll tax riots, the middle of the recession and the end for Margaret Thatcher
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Poll_tax_ri...



Other topics to study should include
The Falklands war
The labour movement and the unions
The miners strike
The printworkers strike
The acid house scene
The Madchester scene



It was  a great time to grow up in hinesight.



</answer>

<answer>



What's funny about fundamentalists on both sides, to me, is this:



Abortion is a hot button issue to presidential races.  Let's take a look at the 10th Amendment, shall we?



The powers not delegated to the United States by the Constitution, nor prohibited by it to the States, are reserved to the States respectively, or to the people.



And the whole Theist or Atheist thing.  Let's read the first Amendment now:



Congress shall make no law respecting an establishment of religion, or prohibiting the free exercise thereof; or abridging the freedom of speech, or of the press; or the right of the people peaceably to assemble, and to petition the Government for a redress of grievances.



So, what did we learn?



People are idiots.

A Republicrat

<question>



The politics of humor?



Hi all, I'm new here and would like some feedback from you guys.



I suppose this is more about the politics of humor.



I am having a discussion on another forum with someone from the US about the US presidential election and the discussion got sidetracked into talking about the legacy of slavery in the US and I suppose how that still affects how people in the North and South feel.



Anyway, at one point this person was answering some questions of mine and posted this...



Quote:
''Buying a slave was on the order of buying a car today, some were more expensive than others but none were really cheap, meaning it was nothing you did on a whim. In 1860 a quality slave would go for $1500 which would be $16,500 or more today. The price depended on lots of things as you’d imagine and others apart from the obvious - the type of work, type of crop, crop prices to some extent and the person’s attitude. Somebody like Tupac would have been cheaper than usual.''



When challenged about the last sentence in that paragraph he said it was a joke.



I personally believe that this joke was completely inappropriate to make in a serious discussion.



I have told him as much and now he is calling me uptight and telling me his Black American friends would have no problem with him making such a joke because they have a 'healthy disposition' with regard such humor.



Anyway, what do you guys think?



Is that joke funny?



Is that the kind of joke an African American would be happy for their White friends making?



Just curious about the nature of humor there in the US.



Thanks for reading, I look forward to your replies.



</question>

<answer from>



stevijan
Member since: 20 November 2006
Total points: 6733 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Other - Society & Culture



</answer from>



<answer>



For one thing, we wouldn't have the pyramids in Egypt.  Slave labor built them.  And Aztecs in the Americas used slave labor to build their pyramid-type structures where they sacrificed people by removing their hearts while they were still alive.  Taj Mahal.  Roman Colliseum.  Lots of famous landmarks wouldn't exist if there hadn't been slaves throughout history.



Doesn't make slavery right, of course, but those are instances of what the world would be like without slavery which is the question you asked.



</answer>

<answer from>



melouofs
Member since: 24 April 2006
Total points: 29801 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



Wow, you really take things seriously.



Honestly, it's just a light-hearted day for kids to dress is costumes and get candy. If you don't wish to have trick-or-treaters, you don't turn on your porch light-that's the signal that you're willing to accept Halloweeners.



I do not equate it with begging because it's a well-known expected thing, and people participate (or don't) at their own discretion.



My husband is a photographer, and every Halloween, he opens the studio to anyone in costume, has a Halloween set and takes their photo. While they're waiting for their picture, he gives them a candy bar and cookies--not because he's forced to, but because it's a wonderful thing to share your blessings and talents with others. The kids are so happy to get the treats, the parents are thrilled to have the picture or their little ones. Families come back year after year--he did 450 kids last year--all free. I cannot understand what's negative about neighbors sharing with each other! Kids do understand they can do this only because it's Halloween-there is no confusion.



</answer>



<answer from>

Member since: 08 May 2008
Total points: 1157 (Level 3)

<question>



Why is hanging considered racial?



Historically more white people have been executed by hanging than black people. So why is hanging considered to be a racist sign against black people nowadays? Both black and white people were lynched so that can't be the answer. Maybe it has something to do with the KKK?



</question>



<additional details>



Even if I was ignorant... which I don't think I am because eveything I say makes sense when you look at logic and not your emotions... at least I'm asking a question about it to learn more. So none of that.

I am black.



and I am racist as no other



</additional details>



<answer from>



Ekman
Member since: 31 October 2008
Total points: 115 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Haha.  All the people calling him ignorant for saying that more whites were hanged than blacks, are you aware that A) the best way to cure ignorance is to ask questions, and B) there is actually another continent outside of the US that some people occasionally refer to as "Europe"?  In case you haven't, all you not-ignorant people, it's a land absolutely FULL of white people who have a long history of using the gallows as the primary means of capital punishment.  Muslim-influenced countries such as those in Africa generally used beheading instead, as well as China and Japan.



On top of that, between 1880 and 1951 the Tuskegee Institute recorded that over a quarter of all people lynched were white, and that's on top of all the legally hanged criminals from thousands of years ago all the way up until 1996.



"Why are people always trying to downplay what minorities face in this country?"



Umm... Because not everybody is so insecure about their morality that they need to flatter minorities at every turn?  Seriously, you guys don't fool anybody.



As for the original question, it's because lynching is far more sensational than hanging, so it is more likely to be remembered, especially since the practice as a legal method of execution has long since been out of common use while we are still reminded of the horrors of lynchings fairly often.  Not to mention everybody is embarrassed that America once acted so inconceivably cruel towards people just because they were different.



</answer>

If our country can't answer the hard questions peacefully, and is offensive whenever race comes up you know we are doomed. From your answers it seems to me U.S.A is full of so many racist people, white and black



</asker's comment>

<answer>

</answer>



<answer from>



Q
Member since: 03 December 2007
Total points: 30707 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Women's Health



</answer from>



<answer>



It's not HANGING that is considered to be racial, it's LYNCHING. That is, mobs of people grabbing blacks and hanging them as part of a whole social event and terrorism party, scaring other blacks in the community into obedience for fear of also being lynched. A noose is considered to be a racist sign because it's one of the ways that racists terrorized blacks in the U.S. Hangings were done more under the aegis of the law, as punishment, not as terror. No one ever went around grabbing white people and hanging them in the middle of the night for fun.



And also, you have a) no evidence that more white people have been executed by hanging than black people, and b) even if we say for the sake of evidence that it is true, you've provided no evidence regarding percentages killed. That is, whites are a majority in the  U.S., so you'd expect greater numbers of them to show up in whatever statistics you have, and blacks are a minority, so smaller numbers will show up. But 5 white people hanged represents a much smaller percent of the white population than 5 black people hanged as part of the black population as a whole.



Also, it's pointless to say something like "Latinos suffer more than African-Americans." You can't quantify suffering, and you can't make a generalization like that--some have it worse than others, some have it better.



</answer>

Ms. Opinionative

<answer>



It's because most people on this site join not to help people, but offend them with hateful answers. Usually, every question has at least one of those types of people, while the higher level or Top Contributors provide the sensible answers. Sure enough, regular members like level 1 could also provide good answers, but that somewhat rare. They're usually trolls.



</answer>



<answer from>

Keep answering and asking questions, don't let the undesirables get to you; there are a lot of nice people here too.

<answer from>



Big



Bird

</answer from>



<answer>



Welcome.
I have found that there are many members here who are bored and looking for some entertainment. They have no intention of trying to help people, they only want a good laugh.
I try to answer question in a way that will help the asker, but some questions are so odd that I just can't help myself from leaving an odd answer.
One thing you can try is whenever you see an answer that bothers you, block that user. This way, you will not get that user answering any of your questions.



</answer>



<answer from>

<answer>



Not everyone is a diplomat and not everyone wants to ***** foot around every subject. This is a questions and answers forum and as such is not an appropriate medium for people to use if they have serious problems etc.  You cannot dictate how other people will answer and you cannot assume you are the only one who knows the "point".  YA is a game - that is the only point and its one you can't even win!

<question from>



Rupesh Jhabak
Member since: 05 February 2008
Total points: 361 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



Importance of Neighbours and the Neighbourhood you live in?



hi all,
i've been given this topic to speak on in my school's assembly..



i'd like if you could help me with a few points and suggestion like where and how and why are neighbours important in our lives/social lives... and what's it like to be good neighbours yourself ! ..



thanks a lot everyone ! :)



</question>



<answer from>



P
Member since: 03 October 2008
Total points: 467 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Neighbors can be part of your tribe.  It's important to have good relations with the people who live next or near to you because, your home is your safe, comfort zone.  The place where you can "let your hair down."  So, neighbors play a vital role in community and also in learning how to and practicing socialization and integration in society.  It also just feels good to have the place where you live be surrounded with good feelings.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



thanks !



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



vinadh
Member since: 09 November 2006
Total points: 289 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Good neighbours are very important. I will give a simple example in my life which illustrates the necessity of having helping neighbours.  Few years back me & my wife had to visit UK to help my daughter' family during her delivary.  I have an very old mother who requires to be looked after in our absence.  Our neighbours voluntarily came forward took the burden of the same.  We in India involve ourselves in the lives of our neighbours(some times it may disturb you/your privacy) but they are the ones who could attend you to help in case of need.  I was totally free to leave India.  Here I want to put few lines how an ununderstanding neighbour would be miserable- during our same visit on the day when my daughter was in hospital with labour pains-it was in the night , as we are not supposed to visit her in the hospital- in a state of anxiety we were awake althrough the night & our lights were on.  The next day the neighbour came up with harsh worded complaint alleging our lights disturbed them as through ventilators light passes to their house.  Their children could not sleep even with little lighting.  Without knowing what made us awake & put on lights during night they complained.  So  neighbours of good nature are most welcome- they are more needed than a friend who could not be in a position to extend his helping hand.



</answer>



<answer from>



popa
Member since: 15 November 2007
Total points: 1734 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



we were considering moving when a new family moved into the other side of our semidetached house.Two children, and they are from Brazil.



We had adopted a Brazilian family when they came to our church and they were expecting a baby they went on to have a second child before returning to Brazil.Both these families are friends our adopted family have returned to the UK.so we are very happy.But it does not stop their we saw that our next door house was up for sale, never spoken to the owner not even a smile.I phone a young couple who were looking to move and wanted to purchase a sun-trap as ours are on this small estate.I said I had found a three bedroom house with the Best Neighbours in the world,wow who are they S & B that's my wife and I.We laughed they came,yes you got it they are moving in this weekend,and are fellow members of our church,so it feels so blessed they came over last night for a meal, but we have a problem now as our Brazilian neighbours ask us in on Christmas's eve our new neighbours also want us with them ain't it great from no friendly next door neighbours to this and they are from India.Yes you gust it our old neighbours were english and never even said "Good Morning" we tried but sorry our smiles words feel on STONE ground.Popa



Source(s):



Food the Brazilian father is a chef and have smoke caviar so yes will put on even more weight.



</answer>

<question>



Question For Brits - Stiff Upper Lip . . . ?



Is the British notion of keeping "a stiff, upper lip", "getting on with it" and not showing emotion (especially in public) considered old fashioned and outdated or is modern Britain just as likely to have these ideals as post-war Britain.



Also, does "a stiff, upper lip", etc.only apply to conduct  in public or do people act this way in private too (if modern Britain does still acts this way)?



</question>



<answer from>



THINK
Member since: 18 March 2008
Total points: 5385 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



no, it is considered especially important and useful feature of our culture especially with whats going on with the economy



</answer>



<answer from>



n b
Member since: 11 February 2007
Total points: 2942 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



We are hard as nails, bring it on



</answer>



<answer from>



Timothy L
Member since: 30 June 2007
Total points: 516 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



What it really means is - don't weep and wail and do the dying duck act. Just accept that what has happened has happened - and how are you going to address/correct the problem ?



</answer>



<answer from>



Riley
Member since: 17 December 2006
Total points: 28626 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



It pretty much means don't carry on like a immature fool in public, and go do the things you need to do, without wasting time. (US Version)



</answer>



<answer from>



forgetyo...
Member since: 01 August 2007
Total points: 6 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



The stiff-upper lip, posh type of accent is no longer prevalent, and is considered an old-fashioned/stuck-up way of speaking. British people are quite unreserved amongst their friends, and outgoing, and can often be quite loud, even in public. However, British people have a manner of being very closed to strangers and people they don't know, and do not show their true feelings or emotions. Speaking to random people in Britian is not considered socially acceptable and people would be quite taken back by such behaviour.



People aren't as reserved as they were before the war, but people are still quite reserved as far as strangers go, I think that's the main distinguishment between reservation towards people.



</answer>



<answer from>



holiday1
Member since: 13 March 2008
Total points: 686 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>

We win wars and we stand up for what we believe in.



Source(s):



A patriot.



</answer>

<question from>



Jay F
Member since: 28 October 2008
Total points: 110 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Some times im two different ppl at nite and day?



im a popular nice cool outgoing guy at day but at nite when i go out im always feeling more free like i have two personalities or some thing i feel more alive i do good things at nite but also bad  anyone know what it means



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



nah, it's fairly normal, it depends on what type of mood you're in. At a night out, you often feel loud and feel like taking risks, whereas in the daytime the mood feels more calm and ordinary and we conform to the mood around us. If your friends are bad at night, it makes you feel like you ought to be so you blend in with the surroundings.



</answer>

<answer from>



star girl
Member since: 15 October 2008
Total points: 122 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



you're probably feeling run-down and not getting enough fresh air/ exercise. Your sleeping pattern seems all over the place. Make sure you don't drink coffee or watch TV before you go to bed, and try not to eat a big meal straight before you go to sleep as it needs time to digest and could prevent you from sleeping. Set your alarm earlier in the morning, so you can take more time getting up and no matter how you feel, take a quick shower in the morning- as this can help you feel more alert and awake, and makes you feel better.
In the daytime, try to do some form of exercise outside, even if its just walking to school/work. This will make you feel more naturally tired for bed. But when you get home, try hard not to fall asleep until its your bedtime and soon your sleeping patteren will get back in sync.
If none of this works, try going to the doctors to check you're not anemaic.
Sorry for the long answer and I hope this helps :)



</answer>

<question>



If Budah had so much self-controll why was he so fat?



I was reading about Budah in my 6th grade social studies book (for thats why grade i am in 6th grade) and they showed a picture of him as the fat little golden statue and they talked about how much self controll he had i don't get it! i just dont! how could he be fat if he had so much self controll it makes so sence!



somene please explain?



</question>



<additional details>



no mean to offend anyone in anyway and so sorry if i did!



The Buddah i am talking about is the Asain one the famous one the one everyone knonws most (i think they should)(the fat little chubby statue)



</additional details>



<answer from>



Suzie!!!...
Member since: 11 June 2008
Total points: 2810 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



thats not actually how he looks, those are just depictions of what people thought he looked like. They have drawings where he looks thin also. Kind of like the images of Jesus, thats not how he REALLY looks...



</answer>



<answer from>



Randall E
Member since: 26 June 2008
Total points: 8362 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Not at all.



It is the Chinese Buddha that is fat, and my understanding is that this is the Buddha already taken up.



Fat is simply a symbol for full, for satisfied, healthy, sated, wealthy, etc....



Siddhartha was not fat.



Buddhist monks in China are not fat, just like thay are not fat anywhere else.



I think the larger message is, if you live the austere life and follow Siddhartha's example, you will find enlightenment and be satisfied.



That satisfaction is depicted on the Chinese Buddha as a belly.



My Buddha statue is marble, 19th century, Burmese.



He is beautiful and not fat.



But the smile on his face is one of contentment, enlightenment.



It is merely a difference in the way different cultures depict the satisfaction achieved through Buddhism's spiritual pursuit.



</answer>



<answer from>



Andre
Member since: 28 October 2008
Total points: 144 (Level 1)



</answer from>

<answer>



Lord Buddha was not that fatty. He possessed self control power but not in all areas. He could not control his bodily nervous system. There is a story. Once Lord Buddha was travelling with his deciple Ananda.
Suddenly he stopped walking. Ananda asked, Prabhu "what happened"? He replied " Ananda, one fly sat on my forehead and suddenly my hand went on my forehead to remove the fly".Ananda said, this is common to every one. This happens automatically. He said, no Ananda. This happened to a man like me. After leading a long life in the area of meditation when everything is in my control, my hand went up to my forehead without my permission: This is something to be thought of. Then what about the normal common people. We will have to be more cautious. Thereafter, it is learnt that Lord Buddha did lot more Tapasya on this and explained many things on the subject.



</answer>

Rhosh R

<answer>



The tru Budah was not Fat "He was Asiatic Blackman, that came from rebelllous of the people , because He guide people to right path to Elightment One the "Supreme Being". Buddhism is 35,000 years old. However, Buddha was born in 500 B.C. This makes Buddhism only 2,500 . According to the definition of Buddhism in the American Heritage Dictionary of the English Language, 3rd edition, published by the Houghton Mifflin Company in Boston, New York, Buddhism is "the doctrine attributed to Buddah..."



The doctrine ( the principle or body of principles presented for acceptance or belief) of Buddhism existed long before the birth of Siddhartha Gautama (Buddah).



The word 'Buddha' is a title and not a name. It means 'one who is awake' in the sense of having 'woken up to reality'. This title was first given to a man called Siddharta Gautama, who lived 2,500 years ago in northern India.



</answer>

Population of pets in America: Less than 69,000,000



You do the math.

<original file>5546.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk94486.txt</current file name>




<category>



Society & Culture



Other - Society & Culture



</category>



<question from>



effie hao
Member since: 26 July 2008
Total points: 87 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Do you think in modern society longer time of sentence in prison is the best way to control crimes?



what extent do you agree?



</question>



<answer from>



Rachel
Member since: 13 June 2008
Total points: 3013 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



I agree with this to some extent.



I live in the UK and some of the sentences handed out for serious crimes such as rape, murder and armed robbery are very lenient to say the least. For these sorts of crimes it is my belief that they should be locked up for life (and life meaning life) unless by some miracle they manage to change their ways, which in most cases doesn't happen.



However for more petty crimes such as shoplifting I don't think a prison sentence should be handed out in many of these cases because most people will commit petty crimes because of social reasons like poverty. If the social reason was addressed then the person wouldn't feel the need to commit the crime, like stealing some food so that they can feed their children. I do think though that they should be punished, perhaps fined or given some community service but is putting a desperate parent or a debt ridden individual in prison really the answer to solving crime? I don't think so because if the offender has children, the child could end up in care if there are no other family members to look after them or the person with the debt will still come out of prison with the debt so are likely to re-offend. I know this is not the case for all petty offenders, but many are desperate and feel there is no other way to try and escape their problems.



Those who commit serious crimes on the other hand often have a psychological issue, which often stems from childhood. Perhaps they suffered abuse when they were younger and commit crime to get revenge for what happened to them.



Another thing is that children in care (so if the authorities put a child of a petty criminal in prison) are more likely to become criminals. So we should be trying to keep the petty offenders with their children if possible. If we separate them then we are risking breeding more serious offenders.



Another thing is what is a crime? What may be a crime in one country may be perfectly acceptable in another country, just like punishments for crimes vary between countries. A good example would be about 3 years ago it was perfectly acceptable to smoke in a pub (uk) but now you are labeled a criminal if you do. Crimes are just laws that over the years have been thought of by whoever was the govt of that time and have then been implemented.



So my answer to your question is..... prison for serious offenders and rehabilitation/ addressing the issues of petty offenders



Source(s):



I have studied criminology and the the different theorists



</answer>



<answer from>



Ivy
Member since: 28 May 2008
Total points: 4552 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



I don't agree at all. Sociological studies have proven that there is no link between crime rate and prison time. And that's in all developed nations.



</answer>
