<answer from>



Jayarama...
Member since: 17 May 2007
Total points: 39200 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Cancer



</answer from>



<answer>



In September 2007, the world's population is believed to have reached over 6.6 billion.



In line with population projections, this figure continues to grow at rates that were unprecedented before the 20th century, although the rate of increase has almost halved since its peak, which was reached in 1963, of 2.2 percent per year. The world's population is expected to reach over 9 billion by the year 2050.-

<question from>



John L
Member since: 29 October 2008
Total points: 68 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Do you believe education is important?



I'm a freshman in college and I absolutely hate that no one truly cares for education. Many of the students I'm around with have their college education, room/board paid off by their parents and they don't take advantage of it. They emphasize too much on their physical nature, partying, and socializing. What's also funny is that half of the people in my dorm floor are gone! as in they either dropped out of college or got in trouble with the law.



I'm really not trying to be offensive to those who don't take their education seriously, but they have the opportunity to learn, when many others do not.



I just want to know your opinions if possible



</question>



<answer from>



stezzog
Member since: 15 June 2006
Total points: 120 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



The more you learn, the more you understand; the more you understand, the better you can cope.



</answer>



<answer from>



Ivy
Member since: 28 May 2008
Total points: 4566 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



This is common during freshman year. These people will be almost entirely weeded out by next year, and you'll start to find more like-minded people. As your education progresses, you will notice a bigger gap between yourself and those who never went to college. (Not that you will be superior, but you will have less to talk about with them, and they will understand less of where you are coming from and what you feel is important.)



</answer>



<answer from>



Rachel
Member since: 13 June 2008
Total points: 3027 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Education is very important but not because you learn geography and history etc. Its the disciplines it teaches and the socializing (and I'm not talking about the Saturday night drinking sessions, I'm meaning the fact that when a young child goes to school they learn how to behave around other people, how to communicate and compromise with others and how to share) It also gets people into a routine (which for young children is very important)



However things you learn in classes such as history and geography are not so important unless you want to be a history/geography teacher or a historian. Apart from that they won't help you learn how to get a job or about things that happen in adult life like debt, budgeting, buying your own house.



So while its important. It doesn't teach you every single thing you need to know in life. When you leave school, college, uni you'll still be learning a lot more. Because not everything is academic



</answer>

<original file>62.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk95212.txt</current file name>




<category>



Society & Culture



Other - Society & Culture



</category>



<question from>



Mackenzie Crook
Member since: 25 April 2008
Total points: 99 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



If you could get ten years' salary in a lump sum, how would you spend it and why?



Watch an exclusive clip of "Three And Out" here:



http://uk.movies.yahoo.com/t/Three-And-O...



</question>



<answer from>



gvih2g2
Member since: 14 August 2006
Total points: 8592 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



I did, when I sold my share in a software company to my partners and "retired" (at 35).



At first it was great - no mortgage or bills to worry about, a quiet life in the country with no commute, and I could act out my fantasy of being a writer for a couple of years and treat myself to a few things I'd always wanted - a sports car, a telescope, an expensive camera, a road-trip holiday through the USA.



But I got depressed (not badly enough to need medical treatment, but enough to stop me enjoying much of life). I got scared, obsessed with "protecting" the rest of the money - and as a result living more cheaply and less well than I had when I was working. I missed the buzz of work and the company of my colleagues.



I'm now back at work, still with no mortgage and no real money worries but with a family who help me spend any cash that's left :-), and in many ways it's almost as if I'd never had the money. I'm in a less-pressured job, but there's enough activity to still get that buzz, and it's great to be amongst people again. So be careful what you wish for!



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Amazing answer, thanks!



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Girly Brains
Member since: 01 March 2007
Total points: 2610 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



On tax!



Why?



Because anything you get is swiftly spirited away by the protection racket* that funds all those £billions of salaries that make the industry called the State. It produces nothing and consumes the planet.



(The Chief Executive of my County Council, for example, gets £220,000 every year, plus perks. That's actually more than the Prime Minister!)



Not a salary, really . . . a lottery win!



Every year, plus perks!



That takes a lot of funding, hence, If I could get ten years' salary in a lump sum, how would I spend it and why?. . .



That's how and that's why!



[*The only difference between the Mafia and the State is that with the Mafia, you actually get protection.



ie, you can walk the street without getting knifed]



</answer>



<answer from>



Laura
Member since: 07 February 2007
Total points: 1669 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



I would firstly put a five figure sum into a secure savings fund for my son's education.



After that I would spend about half the remainder on buying and renovating a property for resale.  This would form the cautious basis of a development business.



The other half would be banked, and I would allow myself a stipend each month from the amount to live on.  If I was working still, this stipend would be a cursory amount, maybe to cover any days I didn't earn, because I was working on the property renovation.



I would also ensure that a percentage of any income from the banked sum or the property development was reinvested into a charitable trust, to be used towards any number of good causes.



And no doubt I'd be tempted to replace my car as she is rather elderly.  But that would take a sizeable chunk from the whole, so that might have to wait.



</answer>



<answer from>



greatbri...
Member since: 27 April 2006
Total points: 1154 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



An interesting proposition.  After deleting the rubbish I was left with 4 answers:- Andy T; Weregunn; Airies6qu and Tori Bell.  They all had merit.  However, the nature of your question is simply that instead of receiving your pay month by month YOU are going to receive it in one lump sum at the outset, after that you are a prisoner to the 'Payer'.
Based on this, you obviously have ti invest your money in such a way that you have an income for the next ten years.
The nearest answer already given which is the most sensible is that of Tori Bell.



However, she overlooked one important detail; you can't invest the lot at the outset because you'll have nothing left to live on.



So the amended solution is that if the economy is stagnating you will have operate progressively.



Keep 10% of the cash fluid;



invest in short term fixed bonds high interest rates say 30%;



10% blue chip stock with good yield relative to depressed market and the remaining 50% in smaller housing 'plots' - this is a loose expression because they can be either new or modern pre lived in.  Being smaller we mean those properties which will appeal to the majority, which in turn means ok for 2/3 persons to live in and in areas where the employment is viable.
Finally, you cannot sit back; you have to be continually reviewing and taking stock to alter investment strategy as you go along.
There is something to be said for a steady safe reliable job connected to Teaching, Local Government or Politics.
No Holidays, No fine clothes, No opposite sex encounters.
Sheer graft for 10 years.
Think on.



Source(s):



Retired Banker who knows his onions.



</answer>

<answer>



Invest it in higher order or the sum will dissipate rapidly.  As a traderand long term investor I can assure you this the case.



The amount of money you earn or receive is irrelevant in terms of becoming financially in dependant as proven by a recent lottery winner who is now 300k in debt.



What is important is 'saving' which attracts money from nowhere to pay the bills.  When you take a leap of faith and save financial miracles happen.



You value, nuture and look after money and money look after you.



I was diagnosed with a meningioma which prevented me from holding down a 'job' yet still I have persisted with my savings plan and it is beginning to flourish.



Dr John Demartini's book "How to make one hell of a profit and still get to heaven" is probably one of the best financial resources for anyone wishing to build wealth and become financially independent.



</answer>

</answer from>



<answer>



If I were to receive ten (10) years salary as a lump-sum, I would invest it all with Post Office Income Bonds.  The sum invested would be in the region of £400,000 - £500,000.  The return would be about 5%+ a year.  Not a massive income, but a person might be able to live on it provided there were no mortgage or rent to pay.



Five percent of £400,000 = an annual income of £20,000.  The UK tax on an income from savings of £20,000 = £4,000 - which leave an income of £16,000 after all income tax has been paid.



I could live with that.



Please note the above income figs are fictional and do not relate to my real income.  They are based upon a persion with an income of between £40,000 to £50,000 p.a.



Source(s):



GREENWICH 300408.0635BST



</answer>

Of course I'd have to pay off a few bills but I'd spend a ton of trying to make sure the Democratic Party conducts its future nominating process in a truly "Democratic" way.



Super delegates may well decide the 2008 Presidential race.  They are not obligated to support the candidate chosen by voters.



From what I have read each super delegate vote is equivalent to about 10,000 democratic votes.  Does the one really represent the 10,000?  Is this really a democratic process?



But, then again, I may just decide to use this money on making a great flick.  I'd hire someone like Steve Lewis and Tony Owens to write a great screenplay and Jonathan Gershfeild to direct it and turn my ten years' salary turn into a fortune!  I could always use the profits to pursue the above.  What do you think?



</answer>

joshofth...

Paul B

<answer>



Hmm...good one. In a way I perhaps shouldn't be answering this as I'm an impoverished student and consequently not earning a salary. However, before that I was an impoverished accounts clerk. Considering that when I was working I was less likely to be paid off with that kind of money than I am to win the lottery this week, I shall proceed on the basis that we're dealing with the realms of fantasy here. So what would I do with the money?



1)Give some to my parents and grandparents as I love them so much and they've been good to me over the years. Very corny I know, but that's how I feel. Also if I could I would bankroll my struggling swordfighting and jiu-jitsu clubs. The people I met there are my best friends and it would mean a lot to me to be able to make sure both clubs were able to keep running, and maybe afford some new equipment too.



2) I'm a total geek who's in love with all things ancient/medieval, so I'd buy myself a few new swords and a nice shiny suit of plate armour.



3) Get a decent guitar? Maybe I'd finally get some motivation up to learn if I had a good one. I'd have to get a massive amp as well. I mean, so big that it shatters the windows whenever I strum a chord. That'll teach the neighbours' kids to practice the trumpet whenever I'm trying to sleep, watch a film or study!



4) Then I suppose I'd have to be uber-sensible and try to invest the rest in something to try and get a return on it. Shares in Northern Rock perhaps? Hmm...Maybe not. I know, I'll ask my old boss, he's an accountant, so should be clued up on that type of thing. Oh wait, hang on. He's the one who's just paid me off. That means that I haven't been injured or traumatised or anything. If this was the case he'd still find a way of keeping me working whilst not paying me anything. He must have bought my silence somehow. Maybe I caught him cooking the books on my way out one night. Either way, he's not going to want to give me any free financial advice.



But, having said all that, even 10 years salary wouldn't have amounted to much in my case, so the plate armour is probably a no-no. And the guitar (Especially the concert amp that was to go with it). Never mind, huh?



</answer>

<question from>



ladybug

</question from>



<question>



What is the relation between Masons and Orion planet?



</question>



<answer from>



AmIHawt
Member since: 13 February 2008
Total points: 876 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Masons? orion planet? are you talking about some sci fi story?



</answer>



<answer from>



B.O.
Member since: 30 October 2008
Total points: 102 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



There is no Orion Planet. Orion is a star.
The Masonic connections are numerous, but the Orion connection is primarily Egyptian, not Masonic. There may be some confusion as many Masonic rituals are based upon the construction of Solomans temple, and the Master Mason Hiram Abiff was Egyptian.
The Ancient Egyptians believed that the departing soul travelled to Orion, and the alignment of the pyramids is in accordance with this belief.



</answer>



<answer from>



Eric H
Member since: 02 April 2008
Total points: 40384 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



Orion is a nebula.



Masons are a silly secret society.



No relation that I can see.



</answer>

<question>



Why is it that Salma Hayek, Penelope Cruz, and Shakira are all considered Latinas when they are caucasian?



Penelope Cruz = 100% Spaniard
Salma Hayek = 1/2 Lebanese, 1/2 Spaniard, born in Mexico
Shakira = 1/2 Lebanese, 1/2 Spaniard/Italian, born in Colombia



All of these women are frequently described as "Latina", but racially speaking, I would say that it would be more accurate to refer to them as Caucasians of Mediterranean origin.  When I think "Latina" I think Mestiza (mixed Native Indian/European) or Native Indian.  Penelope Cruz has NO Indian blood, and Shakira and Salma Hayek probably have very little if any Indian blood and are most likely 100% Caucasian.



Why, then, are they so frequently offered as examples of "Latinas" when, in reality they are Mediterranean Caucasians?



</question>



<answer from>



Dennis J
Member since: 24 September 2008
Total points: 231 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



'Latino' or 'Latina' is not a race. Its more of a nationality. Most of the people who say they are not white but they are 'Latino' are probably wiggers without a racial identity.



People want to mistake any spaniard or latin american person as a non white 'latino' or 'latina' to try and elevate people of indigenous south american descent and deceive their race into thinking that those caucasian women that you mentioned are of their racial group, when in reality they are not and the native people who think that are in denial.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Yeah, I agree, that is exactly how I see it.



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



S
Member since: 22 August 2007
Total points: 8853 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



People don't like to "think" too much. They take what appears to be the obvious conclusion to someone's appearance and go with it, no questions asked. I've been told by many people that I am Filipino or German. My father is German and my mother is half Filipino half Caucasian. They take whatever appeals to them and then they tell me what I am. I was under the impression that I was American, but I guess not.



</answer>

live life to the fullest
Member since: 31 December 2006
Total points: 5880 (Level 5)

Of course, the greater the act of freedom the more you stand to lose that freedom.

Could it be that it is queer not to be intimate with men, than to be intimate with them? I mean in India, men who were afraid to be intimate with men, but would rather be intimate with women were not so long ago thought to be queer, transgendered or unmanly.



Could the western society be putting unnecessary pressures on straight men in order to break them from other men and make them queer?

<question>



How has the "economic crisis" affected you?



Is it real for you yet? Has it affected how you buy things and what you do on a day-to-day basis?



</question>



<answer from>



straight...
Member since: 27 October 2008
Total points: 317 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



It has not affected me yet.



I am having new floors installed in my home (which is a big ticket item) so apparently I dont think I need to sock away all my money under the mattress yet.



My wife and I still spend entirely too much money going out to nice restaurants and having our mid-week trip to the wine bar to relax.



At work, I HAVE seen a decline in my company's work load, and a few of our clients have had to lay-off people and cut back on work they send us.



So far, I think anything that has been done in the business world is just a reaction of what they THINK will come. We shall see if it really ever gets as bad as some people think.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thanks, a bit of optimism among the doom and gloom is not a bad idea at the moment.



</asker's comment>

<question>



Questions for racism .. ?!?



okay so i have to write guiding or research questions about the topic racism.



well i've recently moved to a diff country and some things ive never done. i never did there guiding questions from before and not sure bout it.



I wrote one so far but i dont know if its right : To what extent has racism affected humans?



any other suggestions ??
thanks



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



Effects of Racism



Racism affects people in many ways. Some people take it really seriously when someone tells them that their skin colour looks ugly or the clothes they wear are different to what you wear. Propobly if it happens once, the victim wont take it deeply, but if it continues everyday, the victim will feel really sad, alone and different to others.



Imagine going to a school where everybody dislikes you because of your skin colour or your religion. Racism can lead to hating school and very low self-esteem. Every time victims of racism wake up, they don't want to go to school (or the place where they may see the racist person) and every time they go to school they have a sad face and think "How are the people going to tease me today?"



In the past racism was more common than in these days. Before, people didn't realise what were they doing to people when teasing them (even as a joke). Now, people are not so racist but still a lot of people don't even know what racism is and what it can lead to.



Here are some things that victims can do because they have been the subject of racism:



- skip school lessons
- have problems with learning and education
- change their hair colour
- hate their own religion
- not make any friends
- be scared all the time
- have trouble trusting people



Violence Aside, Racism May Be Harmful to Our Health
In 1990 a 15-year-old African-American male in Harlem had a 37 percent chance of surviving to age 65. The shorter life expectancy of this black child compared with his poor white neighbor on the Lower East Side--who had a 70 percent chance of survival to the same age--has traditionally been blamed on genetics and the effects of poverty.



But what if there were another player in the game? A character that stalks the health of African Americans no matter where they live, what their income or education levels are, or how many drinks or cigarettes they have. A character that wears many masks, including that of poverty. Researchers at the Harvard School of Public Health believe that such a beast exists. Its name is racism.



Nancy Krieger, Camara Jones, and Lisa Berkman research the detrimental health effects of the many forms of racism.



Camara Jones, assistant professor in the Department of Health and Social Behavior and in Epidemiology, Harvard School of Public Health, is a staunch believer that racism is bad for your health. But how can something that starts as an abstract attitude affect one's biology? To explain the connection, Jones uses allegories (see sidebar p. 8) to describe three levels of racism and how each is detrimental to health.



The most visible type of racism, encompassing prejudice and discrimination, is personally mediated racism, Jones says. The black man being beaten for the color of his skin is a victim of this kind of racism, and the effect on his health is easy to see.



When people who have been subjected to racial prejudice and discrimination begin to doubt their own worth and ability, Jones says, they become victims of internalized racism. "The stigmatized people become hopeless and helpless, and those things can impact on health."



Institutionalized racism, characterized by restricted access to well-paying jobs, safe housing, and high-quality health care, is the third classification, and potentially the most profound. "It's because of institutionalized racism that there is an association between social class and race in this country," says Jones.



It is too early to say how much of African Americans' poor health is attributable to institutionalized racism and how much is induced by prejudice and discrimination, but Lisa Berkman, chair of health and social behavior, believes that scientists are now at the brink of being able to look at this empirically.



--------------------------------------...



Levels of Racism: A Gardener's Tale
The following allegory is used by Camara Jones in her class "Race and Racism."



A gardener has two kinds of seed, red and pink, and two flower boxes. One contains rich soil and one has poor, rocky soil. The gardener favors red flowers over pink, so she plants the red seed in the rich soil and the pink seed in the poor soil. Year after year, the rains water, the sun shines, and the gardener harvests the flowers. But she never changes the soil.



The red flowers flourish in the rich soil. But the pink flowers languish--the strongest make it to middling height, the weakest die. The gardener notices the difference, but soon forgets her original decision to put poor soil in one flower box and rich soil in the other. "It's really good that I liked red flowers because they're much prettier," she thinks.



The analogy to institutionalized racism arises from the flowers being contained in separate boxes, and it is perpetuated by the gardener failing to fertilize or mix the soil. An example of personally mediated racism would be if she purpos



</answer>
